Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF A HORSE GEAR AND CRUSHING ROLL"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This horse gear is in the form of a horizontal lever turning on a vertical axis. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1891", "1891-152\u201419,241"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This shows a very general form of machine for applying the power of a horse to the driving of light machinery, such as chaff-cutters, small pumps, etc.; but although larger gears are made to transmit the power of two or four horses, they are not much used in this country when the power required approaches that of a small steam engine.", "The machine has a pole attached to the vertical axis of a bevel wheel of 103 teeth, gearing into a bevel pinion of 12 teeth, whose rotation is transmitted by a shaft coupled by universal joints to multiplying spur gear placed outside the circular horse track.", "The multiplying gear consists of a spur wheel of 76 teeth driving a pinion of 17 teeth, to the shaft of which a pulley is attached for further transmitting the power by belting.", "The horse in going once round the track causes the pulley to make 38.3 rev.", "and when walking at 2.5 miles per hour in a path 25 ft. in diam.", "drives the pulley at 108 rev. per min.", "Scale 1: 8."], "other": ["Scale 1: 8.", "1891-152\u201419,241"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["Worcester"], "descriptions": ["on wooden base", "Motive Power animal power; animal power circa 1891"], "other": ["Model"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a small and compact form of gear patented in 1879 and intended for use with a pony.", "The slow speed of the vertical shaft turned by the animal is multiplied 30.2 times so as to give higher speed to the horizontal shaft from which machinery is to be driven.", "To the bracket that holds the pole is attached a short horizontal shaft, carrying a bevel wheel of 31 teeth and a bevel pinion of 22 teeth.", "The pinion gears into a horizontal bevel ring that forms part of the framing, and a bevel pinion of 16 teeth on the high-speed shaft.", "The bevel wheel gears with a bevel pinion of 22 teeth on a vertical axis in the centre, and this pinion carries gears with a pinion of 16 teeth on the high-speed shaft.", "The motion is transmitted through two Hooke's joints to the external driving pulley", "a pawl gear preventing accidental rotation in the wrong direction."], "other": ["1888-391", "1888"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1879", "1888"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A model of a pony-driven treadwheel gear.", "This gear was designed to increase the speed of a shaft driven by an animal.", "The object demonstrates the principles of mechanical advantage and power transmission."], "other": ["HORSE GEAR"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A wooden platform, constructed as an endless belt, is supported on rollers, and at each extremity passes round a polygonal pulley.", "It is inclined at an angle of 13 deg., giving a rise of 1 in 4.5.", "The horse stands on the sloping platform, which is set in motion by the component of the horse's weight acting parallel to the platform, less the frictional losses, which are considerable.", "The horse's head is haltered to a bar in front, so that he is compelled to walk as the platform recedes.", "Scale 1: 5.", "Motive Power model"], "other": ["1892-92\u201419,250"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF PUMPING WINDMILL"], "makers": ["J. Warner & Sons"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1888"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this windmill, patented by Mr. F. Warner in 1868, the vanes yield as the pressure of the wind increases, and thus automatically adjust themselves to suit its force.", "The mill has 24 radial vanes, mounted between two rings, and each pivoted about its front edge so that the angle which it presents to the wind may vary.", "The ends of the pivots are connected with another ring which is attached to a rod running through the centre of the axle, and connected with a balance weight which keeps adjusting the vanes to such an angle as to make the resultant pressure on them constant.", "A tail is provided for setting the wheel of vanes in a direction parallel to the wind.", "The mill is mounted on a wooden tower and is arranged to drive a small pump from an eccentric on the axle.", "It is stopped by turning the vanes edgeways to the wind by means of a rod attached to the weighted lever."], "other": ["Inv. 1888-298", "19,244"]}

Halliday in 1877.", "The vanes are arranged radially in six groups forming sectors of the complete disc.", "The sectors are pivoted at the middle on axes forming chords of a circle, and levers on them are connected with a sliding sleeve on the axle, which is in turn connected with a weighted lever normally holding the vanes parallel with the wind.", "The angle of the sectors is adjusted by means of a lever and a rope passing over a pulley and attached to the weighted lever.", "The mill is directed by a tail, and is mounted on a tower.", "In the model it drives a pump, at the ground level, from a crank on the axle, but the machine is also used for driving light machinery by gearing and shafting."], "other": ["Scale 1: 12.", "Inv. 1888-297, 19,382."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF BREAST WATER-WHEEL"], "makers": ["Messrs. Whitmore & Binyon"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1888"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this type of wheel the water is laid on at about the level of the axis. The water acts by gravity, and the buckets are so shaped as to retain the water as long as possible during their descent. To ensure rapid filling and emptying, the buckets are ventilated, i.e., a narrow space is left between each on the inner side or sole. The construction of the wheel is wholly in iron ; wrought iron buckets are bolted between two cast-iron spiders with one or more intermediate cast-iron supports, according to the width. The power is taken off by spur gearing, made in segments, bolted to the rim, and is not transmitted through the axle, as in older practice, thus permitting considerable reduction in weight. The sluice gate is controlled by rack and pinion and hand gear. The efficiency of breast wheels is about 55 per cent."], "other": ["Scale 1: 12.", "Inv. 1888-238, 19,364."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Breast-shot Water Wheel"], "makers": ["Whitmore & Binyon"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["c. 1888", "1883-1891"], "places": ["Wickham Market, Suffolk, England, United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["ventilated buckets with rack and pinion operated sluice", "Motive Power waterwheels", "breast shot waterwheels; models; waterwheels; breast shot waterwheels; models"], "other": ["scale 1:12", "Model"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1891"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Smeaton improved the undershot wheel, but it was Gen. J. V. Poncelet who, in 1824, brought it to the high state of efficiency illustrated by the model.", "The characteristic features of his design are the backwardly curved floats and the absence of a sole plate.", "The water is projected on to the wheel buckets tangentially, at the periphery, through a sluice inclined at an angle varying between 40\u00b0 and 60\u00b0 to the horizontal, according to the diameter of the wheel and to the effective head of water.", "The sluice gate is operated by a hand-wheel, spur gear and rack.", "The buckets are proportioned so that the water enters without shock, with the velocity due to the head, and flows up the vanes, until brought to rest by gravity, when it falls, exerting downward pressure.", "The water is discharged from the floats with but little remaining forward velocity.", "In wheels of this type, however the power produced by the weight of the water is negligible compared with that due to its momentum.", "The floats are inclined on the upstream side about 30\u00b0", "the radius of the bucket is usually one-eighth the diameter of the wheel.", "Owing to its slow speed and cumbersome gearing the Poncelet wheel has been displaced by the low-fall turbine.", "The effective head of water should not exceed 5.5 ft.", "the maximum efficiency is 65 per cent."], "other": ["Inv. 1891-109", "19,386"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Poncelet's Water Wheel", "model"], "makers": ["Regnard Fr\u00e8res, 59 rue Bayen, Paris, France", "Poncelet, Jean Victor"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1824 (original)", "1891 (model)"], "places": ["Paris, France"], "descriptions": ["of Poncelet's Undershot water-wheel in masonry pit with rack and pinion operated sluice, on base board.", "Motive Power waterwheels", "undershot waterwheels", "waterwheels"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF PELTON OR \u201c HURDY-GURDY \u201d WATER-WHEEL"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Sandycroft Foundry and Engine Works Co."], "dates": ["1890", "before 1737", "1827", "1874", "1878", "1920"], "places": ["California"], "descriptions": ["form of impulse turbine much used in mining districts and other situations in which a considerable head is available", "high speed and great power render it a most convenient motor", "extreme simplicity minimises the risk of failure", "early form of the machine consisted of a wheel having radial floats or paddles projecting from the upon which a rapid stream of water was directed by a shoot", "reversal or stop of water in such cases were both effected by moving the shoot", "supply generally far exceeding the power required", "Wheels with concave vanes were in use before the year 1737", "Poncelet in 1827 proved their superiority over those with flat vanes", "practical development of this important form of turbine was chiefly effected in the mining districts of California", "original \u201c miner\u2019s wheels \u201d there employed were shrouded and had vanes made as triangular prisms", "had an efficiency of about 40 per cent.", "subsequently improved by the adoption of cup-shaped vanes", "Mr. J. Moore improved these vanes by forming them with a central wedge-shaped ridge which split the jet", "Mr. L. A. Pelton independently arrived at this double construction of cup", "to him the commercial introduction and development of the Pelton wheel is chiefly due", "has a central wheel of cast iron, to the rim of which are secured twenty-eight double buckets of gunmetal 2.3 in. wide", "over-all diameter of the revolving parts being 20 in.", "shaft is carried in three bearings", "near the central one of which a screen or partition would be fitted to prevent water splashing upon the belt pulley by which the power obtained is transmitted", "supply water, which is usually brought through light pipes of sheet steel is, after passing through a sluice valve, led by a conical pipe to a removable discharge nozzle", "by changing the nozzle the load on the wheel may be altered without seriously reducing the efficiency of the motor", "Each bucket or cup consists of two semi-cylindrical portions, uniting in a central ridge which divides the entering water jet", "each half slides round the inside of its cup and has its motion reversed before escaping at the opposite edge", "running the wheel at a circumferential speed slightly less than half the velocity with which the water issues from the nozzle", "the whole of the energy being completely transferred from the cups, dead water is discharged from the wheel", "To facilitate the escape of the dead water from the wheel, the buckets are given a forward inclination", "the wheel must in all cases be above the level of the tail race"], "other": ["Scale 1: 4", "Engineering, 1920, CIX., p. 851", "Inv. 1890-69, 19,362"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["P. Pitman, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1903", "1902", "modern practice"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["MULTIPLE NOZZLE PELTON WHEEL", "When speed requirements call for a wheel of small diameter in which it is not possible to obtain sufficient power with one nozzle, two or more nozzles may be used.", "The jets of water are caused to impinge on the same wheel without conflict so that there is no appreciable loss of efficiency.", "To obtain high efficiency when there is a fluctuating supply of water, one, or two nozzles only may be employed at a time.", "The photograph shows a wheel with three nozzles", "made in 1902 for driving mining machinery", "a feature is the low head of water under which the wheel is operating.", "The runner is of steel plate secured to the shaft by a cast-iron coupling.", "The buckets of bronze, 16 in number, are bolted to the rim, their interior surfaces being ground and polished to minimize friction losses.", "The supply pipe, 24 in. diam., terminates in a chamber to which are bolted three curved pipes, each fitted with a bronze nozzle independently controlled by a gate valve.", "The shaft runs in ring-oiled bearings mounted on cast-iron A-frames bolted to the bedplate, and to the steel plate splash housing.", "The power is taken off by a belt.", "The wheel is 5 ft. pitch diam., and under a head of 60 ft. develops 50 brake h.p. at a speed of 135 r.p.m.", "The efficiency varied from 75 to 80 per cent.  according as one, two or three nozzles were used.", "In modern practice not more than two nozzles are employed on one wheel; if more power is required two runners are mounted on the same shaft."], "other": ["Inv. 1903-183", "photograph"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["servomotor"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1913-466"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A sudden closing of the nozzles, and consequent lifting of the cylinder, will raise the valve and thus open the relief valve, while the loose-fitting piston will afterwards allow the valve rod, which is weighted, to fall slowly, and cause the relief valve to close again.", "The servomotor is mounted on the top of a large tank base, which serves as an oil reservoir, and the pressure is obtained by means of a rotary pump driven by a belt from the turbine shaft; a hand-pump is provided for use when starting.", "The turbine develops 194 h.p. at 600 r.p.m., using 424 cub. ft. of water per min., under a head of 302 ft.", "It has an efficiency of over 80 per cent. over a wide range of load.", "In later practice the nozzle tip is made a fixture and the governor operates a \"cut-off\" which instantly interposes a deflector between the nozzle and the wheel while slowly advancing the needle till the size of the jet corresponds to the load; the deflector is then brought back to its initial position.", "This slow movement is vital to obviate any dangerous rise of pressure in the pipe line."], "other": ["S.M. 350-351", "Inv. 1913-466"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Photograph of engraving of Barker's Mill"], "makers": ["Dr. J. T. Desaguliers", "M. Mathon de la Cour"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1767", "about 1743", "about A.D. 50", "1775", "1839"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["corn mill driven by a reaction turbine", "proposed by Dr. Barker", "similar arrangement had been used by Hero in his steam turbine or aeolipile", "machine consisted of a vertical wooden frame supporting a platform at the top, on which rested the lower and stationary millstone. The upper and movable millstone was attached, passed down through the middle of the frame, and its lower end fitted in a footstep bearing, mounted on a pivoted beam extending across the bottom of the frame. A wide tube surrounded and was fixed to the shaft, and its upper end was furnished with a funnel mouth into which the water was delivered from a supply pipe. The lower end of the tube terminated in two straight, horizontal arms, closed at the ends and each provided with a small orifice, through which the water issued in tangential jets which by their reaction caused the tube and shaft to rotate. The free end of the lower bearing lever was suspended by a long bolt from a bracket on the frame, a nut on the bolt serving to adjust the upper millstone.", "mill in this simple form was only made in small sizes, as it entailed a central tube equal in length to the head of water available, and the mass of water in the tube and arms was carried round as useless dead weight.", "defect was overcome by M. Mathon de la Cour, who, in 1775, proposed to deliver the water directly to the arms of the mill from the upturned end of a fixed pipe, but this improvement was not put in practice until James Whitelaw used it in 1839", "hydraulic efficiency of the simple Barker\u2019s mill is about 66 per cent. and the brake efficiency 60 per cent., this being attained when the linear speed of the orifices is about equal to the velocity of the water due to its head."], "other": ["Ferguson's \u201cMechanics,\u201d 1767", "Inv. 1915-318"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Barker's Mill", "Motive Power photograph"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum"], "dates": ["c. 1767"], "places": ["London, Greater London, England, United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["original form of Barker's Mill"], "other": ["photograph"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF FOURNEYRON\u2019S TURBINE"], "makers": ["T. B. Jordan, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1842", "1827", "four years", "1853"], "places": ["St. Blazien, Baden"], "descriptions": ["This represents the radial outward flow turbine as constructed by Benoit Fourneyron, who completed his first machine in 1827, after having spent four years in experimenting.", "The machine consists of a vertical cylindrical chamber with a side inlet for the water, and a central pipe below through which the water passes to an annular outlet at the base of the pipe.", "This outlet is fitted with thirty guide blades which direct the water in a tangential course as it escapes.", "Surrounding this passage is a runner, keyed to a vertical shaft, and provided with vanes between which the water flows as it passes from the inner to the outer circumference, where it is finally discharged.", "A diagram model of the vanes of such a runner is seen adjoining.", "The water under pressure is discharged in a tangential direction from the fixed guides, and on passing between the vanes of the enclosing wheel has its direction of motion gradually changed until the energy of the water had been transferred to the wheel, when the water is discharged at the outer rims, dead.", "The central pipe containing the guides is carried by three screwed rods connected above by gearing, by which the pipe can be accurately raised, so as to contract the supply passage into the wheel if less than full power is required."], "other": ["The toe of the shaft is carried in a special bearing, supplied with oil under pressure.", "The power given off by the shaft is transmitted by bevel gear at the upper end.", "Inv. 1857-181 and 182\u201419,607."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIAGRAM OF THE NIAGARA FALLS POWER PLANT"], "makers": ["The Niagara Falls Power Co.", "Switzerland", "United States"], "organisations/institutions": ["Institution of Civil Engineers", "Proc. Inst. Mech. Eng."], "dates": ["1896", "1890"], "places": ["Niagara Falls"], "descriptions": ["The available energy of the Niagara Falls is about five million h.p., to generate which by the agency of steam would, it is estimated, require the consumption of the whole of the world\u2019s present output of coal.", "The hydro-electric schemes already in progress will utilise more than a tenth of this energy.", "The diagram shows two of the turbines and their dynamos in the first portion of the scheme of one of the supply companies", "The water is conveyed by an intake canal, 250 ft. wide, 1,700 ft. long, and 12 ft. deep, to the power house, where there is a wheel slot for the turbines, 17 ft. deep and the same in length, cut in the solid rock.", "A tail-race tunnel, 21 ft. high by 19 ft. wide, conveys the dead water to the river below the falls.", "The available fall is 136 ft. and the penstocks are 7.5 ft. diam.", "The turbines, 10 in number and each of 5,000 h.p., are of the twin outward flow type designed in Switzerland and made in the United States.", "A governor and a ratchet relay acting on a cylindrical sleeve on the outside of the wheel regulates the supply.", "The water pressure acts on the cover of the upper turbine, but is relieved from acting on the lower turbine, thus giving an upward pressure counterbalancing the weight of the shaft and the attachments amounting to about 70 tons.", "The dynamo is at the top of the shaft running at 250 rev. per min., giving a voltage of 2,200 with a frequency of 25 periods per second."], "other": ["five million h.p.", "whole of the world\u2019s present output of coal", "more than a tenth of this energy", "first delivered current in 1895", "1895", "250 ft. wide", "1,700 ft. long", "12 ft. deep", "17 ft. deep", "70 tons"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1895"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Diagram of the Niagara Falls Power Plant showing its hydro-electric scheme.", "Includes details on the turbines, dynamos, water intake, and power generation.", "A significant engineering feat of its time."], "other": ["2200 V", "25 Hz"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Proc. Inst. Mech. Eng."], "dates": ["1913", "1915"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["piston valve", "lower end is connected with an eccentric fixed on a shaft that is partially rotated by the movement of the motor piston", "Ports are formed in the valve casing and admit pressure of which the pressure fluid is distributed to either end of the servomotor cylinder", "When the speed increases the governor lifts the piston valve and admits pressure to one end of the servomotor, while the other end is open to the exhaust", "The motion of the piston then raises the compensating sleeve which closes the ports; the piston is thus caused to take up a definite position corresponding with the position of the governor valve, and hunting is prevented", "The valve sleeve is coupled by rolling levers with the oil brake cylinder, which is fitted with a check valve so adjusted that, however sudden the change of load, the action of the governor is not interfered with by the back action of the sleeve", "The governor is fitted with ball bearings throughout, and is constructed so that all parts are accessible", "For starting, the pressure fluid can be admitted directly to the motor cylinder by means of a four-way cock fitted to the supply pipes", "The governor may be worked with either water or oil", "pressure of about 150 lb. per sq. in.", "when using oil it is usually mounted on a self-contained tank bed fitted with the pressure pumps, etc.", "water", "oil"], "other": ["Inv. 1915-125", "150 lb. per sq. in."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["COMPRESSED AIR MOTOR"], "makers": ["Mr. H. J. Kimmans"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1896"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["small portable machine for rotating the tools used in drilling, tapping, tube expanding, etc., by the application of mechanical power, so as to reduce the time otherwise necessary in performing such work by hand labour alone.", "sectional example shown is a piston motor", "four fixed single-acting cylinders arranged in pairs in two planes at right angles", "driving a two-throw crankshaft having cranks at 180 deg.", "Two pistons are connected with each crankpin, so that a fairly uniform turning effort shall be maintained.", "connecting-rod ends are in the form of hinged clips embracing their crankpin, one being forked and bearing outside the other; the ends also embrace the rods, to which they are secured by screwed sleeves.", "Each pair of cylinders is provided with a hollow piston valve, sliding in a bush and driven by an eccentric; the valve admits air to each cylinder alternately, through suitable ports in the casing and bush, which allow exhaust takes place along the axis of the valve.", "cylinders and crankshaft are enclosed in a casing which forms an air chamber, and is provided with a cover through which passes a screwed sleeve with a star handle, for feeding the drill.", "tool holder runs on a ball thrust bearing, and has a conical socket for drills and an externally screwed boss; it is driven from the crankshaft by spur gearing which reduces the speed in the ratio of 1: 7.", "cylinders are 2 in. diam., 2 in. stroke, and the brake h.p. exerted is 1.5, with a consumption of 35 cub. ft. of free air per min.", "air pressure used is from 70 to 100 lb. per sq. in., and the maximum duty of the machine is to drill, in metal, holes of 2 in. diam."], "other": ["Inv. 1901-44", "piston motor", "two-throw crankshaft", "ball thrust bearing", "spur gearing"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1914", "1885"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["hydraulic engine for organ blowing", "valve gear of which was patented by Mr. H. Bamford", "The piston-rod is connected directly with the bellows, and water is admitted to either end of the working cylinder by a piston valve.", "This valve is itself moved by the pressure water which is distributed by a small auxiliary slide valve driven from the piston-rod by a tappet-gear.", "The engine has a horizontal working cylinder, with the valve chest on top. The main valve consists of four pistons, connected together and sliding in a cylindrical casing which is provided with suitable inlet and exhaust ports. The two inner pistons serve to distribute the pressure water to the end of the working cylinder, the space between them being in communication with the water inlet, while the two outer pistons are packed with cup leathers and work in the closed ends of the casing. These ends serve as cylinders, to which the pressure water is admitted alternately by the auxiliary valve, through ports in the main valve stem, so as to cause the piston valve to move from end to end. The valve stem between the two inner pistons is of rectangular section, and the necessary slide valve is applied to its upper face. Three ports are formed in this face, the outer ports leading to the ends of the main valve and the central one to the exhaust, while side lugs are formed on the auxiliary valve to keep it in place, and to serve as abutments against which the arms of a forked lever bear when moving the valve. This lever is mounted on a shaft which passes through a stuffing-box and has on its outer end a slotted lever connected with a rod which is worked backwards and forwards, through a short distance at each end of the piston stroke, by a tappet-rod fixed to an arm on the piston-rod. The tappets are adjustable so that the valve may be set to reverse the motion without shock.", "When the piston nears the end of its stroke, the tappet-gear carries the auxiliary valve in the same direction, thus admitting the pressure water to the opposite end of the piston valve, and driving it in the same direction so as to admit water behind the piston to drive it back. A sectioned valve chest is shown beside the engine."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-139 & 396", "Presented by S. J. Ambler, Esq.", "Mr. H. Bamford"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["WATER MOTOR WITH OSCILLATING CYLINDER", "de Haag's high-pressure water motor"], "makers": ["Messrs. W. H. Bailey & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1894"], "places": ["mine workings", "mine sump"], "descriptions": ["working", "small example", "for pressures up to 300 lb. per sq. in.", "frequently used in mine workings, the water for driving being obtained from the delivery pipe of the main pumping engine, and the motor discharging its exhaust water into the mine sump.", "The cylinder of the engine oscillates on two hollow trunnions, closed at the outer ends, the hollow spaces within each trunnion being divided into two compartments, one of which on each side communicates with either end of the cylinder. Two slots cut longitudinally in the trunnion serve for ports for admission and exhaust of the water, one giving admission to each end of the cylinder, and the lower part of each bearing there are three ports, a wide one in the middle communicating with the supply pipe, and a narrower one on each side of this leading to the exhaust pipe. The oscillation of the cylinder causes those ports in the trunnions to slide over those in the bearings, so opening up each end of the cylinder to exhaust or pressure alternately, just as in the case of an ordinary slide valve. The supply and exhaust pipes are each fitted with an air vessel to prevent shocks in the pipes.", "has a cylinder 2.5 in. diam. by 4 in. stroke", "when making 100 r.p.m. under a pressure of 150 lb. gives off 1 brake h.p.", "Larger sizes are made up to those having 9 in. cylinders", "running at 50 r.p.m. exert 24 brake h.p. under 150 lb. pressure."], "other": ["1894-182", "19, 384"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TIDAL MOTOR"], "makers": ["Richard Roberts"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1858", "1848"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["apparatus, patented by Mr. Roberts in 1848, is shown arranged for clock-winding, or doing lighthouse work, by tidal energy.", "The machine is erected over a tank or well to which the tide has access; into this hangs a weight and also a float, connected by a chain that passes over a sprocket wheel on the overhead shaft, then round a loose wheel on the framing and back over another sprocket wheel.", "These wheels are connected with the shaft by ratchet and pawl mechanism, which causes both upward and downward movements of the float chain to rotate the shaft, always in one direction.", "The power so obtained will cease for a while during the turn of the tide, and therefore when continuous motion is required, an additional mechanism is added.", "On the end of the intermittently rotated shaft is a sprocket wheel, and on the shaft to be continuously rotated, which is in line with it, is another sprocket wheel; over the two wheels hangs an endless chain, in the loops of which are two weighted sheaves, one of which is much the heavier, the difference being the driving weight.", "When the tidal motion is rapid the excess power is stored by lifting the weight, while, when the tidal movement stops, this weight gives off its stored energy in descending, and so keeps the driving shaft in motion.", "The weighted sheaves are connected by a hanging chain which prevents the inequalities in the effort which would otherwise arise from the varying length of chain on the driving side.", "tidal energy", "clock-winding", "lighthouse work"], "other": ["Inv. 1858-9"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DRAWING OF APPARATUS DESCRIBED BY HERO"], "makers": ["Hero of Alexandria"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1897", "1914"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Prepared in the Museum, 1897.", "a philosopher who flourished probably about A.D. 50, in his treatise on \u201cPneumatics\u201d describes a light ball, supported by a jet of high pressure steam issuing from a pipe terminating in a cup, and supplied from a cauldron.", "consists of a hollow ball mounted on its axis between two pivots, one of which, being hollow, serves as a steam pipe from the cauldron below, supporting the whole.", "The ball is provided with two bent nozzles, in a plane at right angles to the line joining the pivots.", "The reaction or unbalanced pressure due to the escape of the jets of high pressure steam tangentially to the ball, causes it to revolve on its axis.", "The reconstruction of an aeolipile shown is based on drawings dating only from about the 15th century however, accompanying the MSS. of Hero\u2019s \u201cPneumatics.\u201d"], "other": ["Inv. 1897-111, 20,691.", "Inv. 1914-398, S.M. 558.", "working", "Made in the Museum.", "Made in the Museum, 1914."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Prepared in the Museum (drawing preparer)"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1897"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["French engineer and architect proposed and published in 1615 an application of steam as a means of elevating water.", "His scheme required a spherical copper boiler with an internal pipe reaching nearly to the bottom, and with a cock for filling it.", "The boiler was to be placed on a fire until the steam pressure forced the boiling water through the vertical pipe to a height proportionate to this pressure.", "In an alternate scheme he proposed using the heat of the sun\u2019s rays to increase the pressure of a confined volume of air, and thus force up some of the water upon which it pressed."], "other": ["Inv. 1897-112", "19,606"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Drawing of machine designed by Giovanni Branca", "Giovanni Branca Machine designed c. 1629"], "makers": ["Giovanni Branca"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1897", "c. 1629", "1897"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Italian engineer who, in 1629, published a work in which he suggested a form of steam engine.", "A powerful horizontal jet of steam was to be directed against vanes on the circumference of a fan wheel with a vertical axis, thus causing the wheel to revolve.", "Several applications of the resulting motion were described, but that shown in the drawing consists in the use of a reducing train of spur gearing by which pestles or gravitation stamps are lifted.", "The alteration in the form of the jet and in that of the vanes it will, however, be seen, resemble the efficient steam turbine of Dr. de Laval (see No. 152), provided the requisite high speed could have been maintained.", "drawing"], "other": ["Inv. 1897-113", "19,243"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["drawing of apparatus of Torricelli and von Guericke", "mercurial barometer", "syringe"], "makers": ["Evangelista Torricelli", "Otto von Guericke"], "organisations/institutions": ["Physics Collection"], "dates": ["1643/1654", "1897", "middle of the 17th century", "1672", "19,599"], "places": ["Magdeburg"], "descriptions": ["Drawing prepared 1897", "This drawing is inserted here to emphasize the fact that in the middle of the 17th century the discovery was made that the atmosphere had weight and that it could be excluded from a closed vessel so as to obtain a vacuum, facts essential in the development of the steam engine.", "Evangelista Torricelli, an Italian physicist and a pupil of Galileo, in 1643 confirmed his instructor\u2019s speculations that the atmosphere had weight by measuring it with his invention of what is now known as the mercurial barometer.", "Otto von Guericke, burgomaster of Magdeburg, directed his attention to the means of obtaining a vacuum and adapted the syringe for his purpose; in 1654 he showed his apparatus publicly.", "In the treatise he published in 1672 he described a number of experiments on the subject, including the one shown in the drawing in which a cylinder is fitted with a tight piston connected by a cord and overhead air-pump to a weight; when the air under the piston was exhausted by an air-pump the weight was lifted."], "other": ["Inv. 1897-114"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DRAWING OF SAVERY'S PUMPING ENGINE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Royal Society", "Philosophical Transactions"], "dates": ["1897", "1698", "1699"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Prepared in the Museum. In 1698 Thomas Savery patented an apparatus \u201cfor raising of water and occasioning motion to all sort of mill works, by the impellent force of fire.\u201d No drawing of the arrangement was deposited, but in the following year a model of the machine was shown at the Royal Society, and is illustrated in their Philosophical Transactions. The apparatus in its simplest form consisted of a high-pressure boiler supplying steam to a receiver, which was provided with suction and delivery pipes and the corresponding valves. By means of a regulator valve worked by hand, steam from the boiler was admitted into a receiver which, acting through it till the air had been expelled; then the supply of steam was cut off and cold water from a cistern above was turned on to the receiver which, acting as a surface condenser, condensed the steam, so forming a partial vacuum into which the water rose from the suction pipe, the delivery orifice being at the same time sealed by its valve; the entering water further assisted in this condensation. Steam was then again admitted, and by its pressure forced the water in the receiver out through the delivery valve and pipe, the suction pipe in the meantime being closed by its non-return valve. (See Phil. Trans. XXI. 1699, p. 228.)"], "other": ["Inv. 1897-117", "19,391", "apparatus \u201cfor raising of water and occasioning motion to all sort of mill works, by the impellent force of fire.\u201d", "model of the machine"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Jacob Leupold, in 1724\u20137, published a sketch and description of a proposed high-pressure engine for working a force pump.", "There were to be two vertical single-acting steam cylinders, two pumps and two rocking beams; but the steam and exhaust for both cylinders were to be controlled by a single four-way cock, so that the cylinders worked alternately.", "The weight of each steam piston was to exceed that of the pump plunger at the other end of its beam so that the in-strokes would be done by gravity, while the exhaust steam passed into the atmosphere.", "The use of a non-condensing engine and of a four-way cock, which Leupold pointed out could be worked automatically, are the leading features in this proposal."], "other": ["Inv. 1897-121"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ENGRAVING OF NEWCOMEN'S ENGINE NEAR DUDLEY CASTLE"], "makers": ["Thomas Newcomen", "Thomas Savery", "Henry Beighton", "Humphrey Potter"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1712", "1719"], "places": ["Staffordshire", "Dudley Castle"], "descriptions": ["shows the steam engine erected in 1712 by Thomas Newcomen in Staffordshire, near Dudley Castle.", "Evidence pointing to the belief that it was the first one constructed by him.", "appears as joint inventor, because it was under his patent of 1698 (see No. 44) that Newcomen's engine was exploited, although it was a totally different apparatus from that of Savery.", "the earliest known document establishing the invention of the atmospheric engine, and is of great interest as showing that, at the date of publication in 1719, automatic valve gear had been evolved; indeed there is nothing to suggest that it was not in existence in 1712.", "The names of Henry Beighton and Humphrey Potter have been associated with this improvement.", "A table of numbered references in letterpress at the sides of the print gives interesting particulars of the several parts of the plant.", "The principle of action of the Newcomen engine will be understood from the preceding description (No. 49).", "The means whereby the engine was enabled to become self-acting was a new invention of far-reaching importance.", "This was the valve gear which was worked by a sliding beam or plug rod attached by chains to a smaller arch-head on the beam and extended below to work a plunger pump for filling the cistern, whence injection and other water supplies were drawn.", "This plug rod actuated the regulator or steam valve, which was simply a sector-shaped plate, at the end of each down stroke and of each up stroke.", "A stirrup attached to the regulator was jerked to and fro by a Y, or forked tumbler bob, fixed to the same shaft, as were two tappets struck by pins in the plug rod.", "The F-shaped injection cock handle was held by a catch till tripped by a rod projecting from a buoy floating on the surface of water inside a pipe passing through the top of the boiler.", "The print affords evidence that the duty of tripping the injection cock had been, at the date of the print, transferred to the \"scoggen,\" a hinged bar struck by a pin in the plug rod.", "The pause at the top of the stroke was suppressed so that a greater number of strokes were made in a given time; this would explain Reference 13, \"Scoggen and his Mate, who work Double to the Boy, \u03b3 is the Axis of him.\"", "The table of references shows that the cylinder of the engine was of brass 21 in. diam., 7 ft. 10 in. long, supported above a boiler 5 ft. 6 in. diam., and 6 ft. 1 in. high, containing 13 hogsheads (700 gall.).", "The pump work was in two lifts, each of 75 ft."], "other": ["but few copies are known to exist", "inv. 1912-37", "S.M. 300", "No. 44", "No. 49", "See \"Engineering,\" LXXXIII, 61"]}

Prosser, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["British Museum"], "dates": [], "places": ["near Dudley Castle"], "descriptions": ["This is a reproduction, reduced in size, from a copper-plate engraving dated 1725, preserved at the British Museum, which has, at the sides, the letterpress shown. It is interesting as showing the advances made in the interval between the engine erected near Dudley Castle in 1712 (see No. 50) and this one.", "The boiler is fed partially with the hot water coming from the bottom of the cylinder, and as a result the number of strokes has increased from the 10 or 12 strokes previously known to about 16 per min.", "There are two gauge cocks to the boiler, which enable both high and low water to be tested; there is also a dead-weight safety valve.", "An independent jack head pump, instead of the plug rod, supplies the injection water cistern.", "The valve gear has the buoy arrangement.", "engine erected near Dudley Castle in 1712", "No. 50"], "other": ["Inv. 1906-22"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Newcomen Engine"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Inst. Min. Eng."], "dates": ["1917", "1920"], "places": ["Pentrich"], "descriptions": ["The piston is shown in the position that is reached when the engine stops working, but the weight of the pump rods would, in practice, quickly bring the piston to the top of the stroke.", "To start work, steam is blown through the cylinder till well heated up, the injection cock is opened by hand, and the engine maker the downward, or power stroke, by the pressure of the atmosphere on the piston.", "As the latter nears the bottom of its stroke, a tappet on the plug rod cuts off the injection water, and by raising the detent, which slips under it, prevents the decisive valve opening during the up-stroke.", "At the bottom of the stroke the steam valve is opened and the pressure on both sides of the piston being equalised, the overweight of the pump rods raises the piston.", "On nearing the top of its stroke the tappet on the plug rod closes the steam valve and the injection valve detent is released, thus enabling the engine to repeat the cycle of operations automatically.", "The pump rods, bolted together at the top, were carried down to three separate lift pumps in the shaft, situated 120 ft., 210 ft. and 360 ft. below the surface respectively.", "The pumps are single acting buckets (a spare one is shown)", "the lowest one being 12.75 in diam., the upper ones each 12.5 in. diam.", "and the stroke, originally 7 ft. was altered to 6 ft.", "so that at its normal rate of eight pumping strokes per min.", "and a pressure on the piston of 7 to 7.5 lb. per sq. in., which was that considered to be the most economical in these engines, the h.p. would be 25;", "about 250 gallons per min. were raised to a height of 360 ft.", "The engine is shown in its correct surroundings, materials having been brought from Pentrich for the purpose.", "Anderson", "Trans. Inst. Min. Eng., 1917, LII, 396\u2013445."], "other": ["Inv. 1920-124"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF ATMOSPHERIC ROTATIVE ENGINE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1912", "1790", "1875", "close of the eighteenth century", "after 1798"], "places": ["Morley, Yorks", "the \u201cCrank Mill\u201d"], "descriptions": ["This represents the atmospheric engine erected in 1790 in the \u201cCrank Mill\u201d at Morley, Yorks. This mill was the first in the neighbourhood to be driven by steam power, and the engine remained in use till 1875, about which time this rough model was made.", "In order to meet the great demand that arose at the close of the eighteenth century for engines to turn mill work, those people who did not wish to pay the royalties for Watt\u2019s patent engine were obliged to adapt the Newcomen engine to work rotatively.", "The method finally adopted was to fit the outdoor end of the beam with a connecting rod to a crank on the mill shaft, to which was fixed a fly-wheel heavily weighted on the crank side so as to store one half of the work done on the downward and restore it in the upward stroke.", "The flexible connection between the piston rod and beam was retained, but after 1798, when the patent for the parallel motion expired, this mechanism was usually added, as shown in the model.", "The cylinder is 2.2 in. diam., and the stroke 4.8 in.", "The steam and injection cocks are worked by tappets in a plug frame hung from the beam by a link and sliding in guides.", "The eduction pipe for condensed steam and air terminated in a hot well.", "A photograph from an early sketch of the Crank Mill is adjacent."], "other": ["Scale about 1:12", "(15816)", "Inv. 1912-78", "Inv. 1920-659", "S.M. 1285"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["air-pump", "piston"], "makers": ["Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["the top of the closed vertical tube\u2014which is the separate condenser\u2014projects a small tube closed by a snifting valve, opening outward", "The condenser and air-pump were enclosed in a cistern of cold water", "the air-pump was fitted with a piston", "A sectional drawing of the apparatus is attached", "the model is now soldered together in an unworkable manner", "Possibly Watt, after his experiments and before his patent was secured, felt that the model might fall into dishonest hands, and therefore left it in this misleading shape, with the steam jacket opening into the condenser and the hole in the cylinder end, and at J soldered over", "That the condenser pipe E originally joined the cylinder at the now closed hole at J is proved by the curved notch filed in the cylinder cover, which notch is now purposeless, but would be necessary with the condenser in the higher position", "the short pipe from J into the cylinder also admits of no other explanation", "Steam to the jacket entered at B", "there is a small hole in the lower cover of the cylinder to act as a drain", "By a cock, steam was admitted into the cylinder through the now closed hole in the top cover, and filling the cylinder it blew through into the upper part of the condenser and out at the snifting valve at G", "When all air had been displaced the cock was shut and the piston in the air-pump H was pulled up by hand, thus leaving an exhausted and cold chamber at F into which the steam from the cylinder rushed and was immediately condensed", "As the weight then lifted by the piston was 18 lb., the condenser pressure was nearly 12 lb. below that of the atmosphere, corresponding to a vacuum of 24 in. of mercury"], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1267", "G"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ORIGINAL MODEL OF A SURFACE CONDENSER"], "makers": ["Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["Watt Collection"], "dates": ["1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["complete, and shows an excellent surface condenser and air-pump", "The condenser is circular, and is traversed by 140 small tubes soldered into a metal tube plate at each end. The cooling water passes through the interior of the tubes.", "A vertical air-pump is attached to the side of the casing, and consists of two tubes united below. The short one is the barrel of the air-pump and is fitted with a solid piston. The longer one is fitted with a delivery valve at the top, and a suction valve where it is connected with the lower end of the condenser.", "The exhaust steam entered the upper portion of the condenser, and the lower outlet opened into the column of the air-pump in such a way that the rising and falling of the water column with the motion of the air-pump piston removed all air from the condensed water.", "In this way an excellent vacuum would be maintained, and modern engine air-pumps are only found efficient when they accord with the principles here observed by Watt.", "Through the difficulty found in maintaining this form of condenser tight, Watt soon discarded it for the jet form, but now with improved methods of construction the tubular surface condenser is the form most in use, chiefly owing to the supply of pure water that it gives ready for returning into the boiler."], "other": ["Plate II., No. 2", "Inv. 1876-1268, 11,866, S.M. 801 and 804."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PORTIONS OF BOULTON AND WATT PUMPING ENGINE", "one length of pump barrel"], "makers": ["Branson & Gwyther"], "organisations/institutions": ["Newcomen's engine"], "dates": ["1777 (in context of improvement)", "1848"], "places": ["Soho, near Birmingham"], "descriptions": ["The parts here preserved belonged to the \u201cOld Bess\u201d pumping engine which was erected in 1777 by James Watt at Matthew Boulton's manufactory, Soho, near Birmingham.", "The engine embodied the separate condenser, the first improvement made by Watt upon Newcomen's engine.", "Watt first knew him was a manufacturer of ornamental metal articles and used water-wheels to drive his machinery.", "In dry weather when the flow diminished six to ten horses had to be brought in to assist; to lessen such expense, this pumping engine was installed to pump water from the tail race back to the head race, as shown by the adjoining model (see No. 66), a practice not unknown even after Watt had made his engine rotative.", "The steam cylinder is 33 in. diam., the stroke is 7 ft. and the pump is 24 in. diam.", "On being dismantled a small furnace beneath the steam cylinder was discovered.", "It is known that in his very early engines Watt used such a furnace to re-evaporate the water which condensed in the steam case and thus reduce steam consumption.", "The engine remained in use till 1848, when the business was discontinued.", "The original parts are the steam cylinder; the piston and piston rod, shown apart; the beam complete with chains and plummer blocks;"], "other": ["15816", "1861-45", "Inv. 1861-45"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["James Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["Boulton\u2019s manufactory", "Kinneil"], "dates": ["1769", "1773"], "places": ["Soho", "Scotland", "Birmingham", "Hull", "London"], "descriptions": ["working model", "constructed from the data given by the existing portions of the engine, together with those on two early drawings", "shows the general arrangement of the engine erected at Boulton\u2019s manufactory at Soho in 1777", "James Watt\u2019s first steam engine was constructed and tried at Kinneil in Scotland in 1769, and was sent to Birmingham in 1773.", "At Kinneil the engine, although it had a separate condenser (see No. 62) and embodied other improvements, was hardly a success owing to its defective mechanical construction.", "When Watt joined Boulton the engine and boiler were conveyed from Scotland by water via Hull to Birmingham, and for two years the engine was being rebuilt and improved, until, with a new bored cast-iron cylinder, 2 ft. stroke, it worked fairly well.", "It was known as \u201cBeelzebub,\u201d and had an 18 in. cylinder, 5 ft. stroke, and worked an 18\u00b75 in. pump against a 24 ft. head.", "In 1777 it was injured by fire, and \u201cOld Bess\u201d was constructed immediately afterwards; it was, however, of considerably more power, as the steam cylinder is 33 in. diam. with a 7 ft. stroke, and the pump has a diam. of 24 in.", "Its duty was to pump water from the tail-race back into the head-race of a water-wheel of 24 ft. diam. and 6 ft. breast, at times when the stream flow was insufficient.", "This indirect method of obtaining rotatory motion by steam power had previously been employed in London and elsewhere.", "Long after the introduction of the rotative steam engine, however, this method of driving was still practised for textile machinery, owing to the more regular motion that it was considered was obtainable by the intervention of a water-wheel.", "The power lost must, however, have been considerable, for if the mechanical efficiency of the water-wheel and its gearing was 50 per cent. and that of the pumps 80 per cent., the combined efficiency could only be 40 per cent., which would be only one-half of the mechanical efficiency of a directly rotative engine, so that twice the amount of coal then necessary would be consumed in doing the required work."], "other": ["Plate II., No. 3", "Inv. 1894-151, 21, 530, S.M. 229"]}

Boulton and Watt in 1788", "Differs only in detail from the standard Cornish pumping engine subsequently so extensively used", "Engine valves are of the drop type", "Connected by racks and segmental arms with levers struck by tappets on the plug or air-pump rod", "Top valve admits steam to the cylinder and was known as the \"expansion\" valve", "Shut off when the piston was at about half-stroke, allowing the remainder of the stroke to be performed by the expansion of the steam previously admitted which performed the work upon the boiler", "Lower or \"equilibrium\" valve is opened when the piston reaches the bottom of its stroke, allowing the steam above the piston to pass to the lower side", "By the weight of the pump-rods the piston ascends to the upper end of the cylinder", "Lowest valve controls the passage from the lower end of the cylinder to the condenser, and is open throughout the down-stroke of the piston", "High economy of these engines is largely due to their acting somewhat as if compounded", "Upper portion of the piston and cylinder are never exposed to the low temperature of steam discharging into the condenser", "Cylinder also has a steam jacket", "Closed top cylinder here employed was introduced by Watt in 1774", "Boiler shown is of the \"wagon\" type", "Probably worked at about 5 lb. per sq. in. above atmospheric pressure"], "other": ["Scale 1: 28", "Prepared in the Museum", "Inv. 1897-123"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Edward Bull", "Trevithick", "Newcomen"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1765-6"], "places": ["Cornwall"], "descriptions": ["This arrangement of direct-acting pumping engine was proposed by Watt in 1765-6 when introducing his separate condenser, but abandoned in favour of the beam construction adopted by Newcomen.", "It is now usually known as the \"Bull\" engine, owing to its having been introduced and constructed on a practical scale by Edward Bull, who, in conjunction with Trevithick, erected several important pumping plants in Cornwall.", "They were, however, infringing Watt's patents, and in 1793-5 were stopped by legal proceedings.", "The cylinder is supported over the pumping shaft by beams extending across the engine house, and the main rod passes through the bottom of the cylinder and is directly attached to the pump spears, the weight of which performed the downward stroke of the pump (in the model it is assisted by a leaden weight).", "Beneath the cylinder is a short rocking beam by which some of the weight of the spears is counterbalanced, and from which the motion for the valve gear and air-pump is obtained.", "From the sectional model it is seen that the exhaust pipe is provided with a jet and used as a condenser, which is cleared by a vertical air-pump; the jet is, however, intermittent, being controlled by the valve gear so that it is only turned on during the exhaust stroke."], "other": ["Watt", "Inv. 1876-1254a", "1513", "S.M. 831", "S.M. 837"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1765", "1775"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A model of a \"Bull\" engine, an inverted cylinder pumping engine.", "This engine type was first conceived by James Watt in 1765.", "It was later developed by Edward Bull and Trevithick, who were contemporaries and inventors in the field of steam engines.", "The engine features a direct-acting mechanism where the piston rod is directly connected to the pump spears."], "other": ["1876", "SMG 831", "SMG 837"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["rotative beam engine"], "makers": ["Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["Boulton and Watt"], "dates": ["1781\u201384", "14 years"], "places": ["distillery near Whitechapel Road", "Durward Street"], "descriptions": ["engine was to be of 10 h.p., having a cylinder 17 in. diam. by 5 ft. stroke, to be used for grinding malt or other grain and for pumping water, \u201cworts\u201d and \u201cwash.\u201d", "adapting the engine to produce rotative motion in order that it might enter the wide field of industrial employment was made by Watt in 1781\u201384.", "Forestalled in the use of the crank, he schemed several equivalent mechanisms (see No. 174\u20138)", "he made the engine double-acting and invented the parallel motion to take the place of the flexible connection between the piston rod and the beam.", "Boulton and Watt sold their pumping engines on a royalty of one-third of the saving in coal resulting as compared with an atmospheric engine doing the same work, and on the introduction of their rotative engine adopted a \"premium\" similarly based on the saving resulting as compared with the power (e.g., of 10 horses) which was replaced.", "payment to the former of an annual premium of 63l. during the unexpired term (i.e., of 14 years) of Watt's patent."], "other": ["Inv. 1908-185"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF DOUBLE CYLINDER ENGINE"], "makers": ["Isaac Mainwaring", "Matthew Murray", "Jabez Hornblower", "Isaac Mainwaring (patented)"], "organisations/institutions": ["Watt Collection"], "dates": ["1792 (Patent)", "1876"], "places": ["Manchester"], "descriptions": ["Two cylinders single acting have their piston rods connected by a chain over a wheel so that, working alternately, they are equivalent to one double-acting cylinder.", "Isaac Mainwaring, in 1792, patented a twin-cylinder engine in which the piston rods were racks gearing into a toothed wheel on the axis of the beam.", "This patent was taken over by Matthew Murray and Jabez Hornblower, who developed the invention into the form shown by the model, and actual engines were made in Manchester.", "The chain passes over and is fixed to a grooved pulley carrying a crank pin at the back which might drive a pump rod or a connecting rod.", "The upper ends of the cylinder are closed but in free communication, and a non-return valve in each piston will permit steam to pass upwards into this space.", "Below the foot of each cylinder is an air pump and condenser, the air pump rods being similarly connected by a chain (parts missing); at the foot of each cylinder is a steam valve and an exhaust valve, by which communication is opened in turn with the boiler and with the jet condenser, which is in the eduction pipe leading to the condenser."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1264", "(parts missing)"]}

Boulton and Watt", "erected in 1797 for John Maud, chemist and druggist", "continued working until 1885", "taken down and presented to the Museum", "8 nominal h.p.", "cylinder 16 in. diam. and 4 ft. stroke", "altered by the makers to a 12 h.p. engine", "diameter of the cylinder being increased to 19.25 in.", "low-pressure condensing engine, with sun and planet gear, similar in general construction to No. 73, but the valves are driven by a crank motion instead of by tappets, and there is a separate cut-off valve moved by a cam motion to give expansive working. The crank and cam are both on a counter-shaft driven by spur gearing, at one-half the speed of the flywheel shaft, which, on account of the sun and planet gear, makes two revolutions for each double stroke of the engine. The connecting rod from the valve can be disengaged, with a gab end, so that it can be disengaged, and the valves be worked by hand levers when required in starting the engine. The engine was probably made with a tappet motion in the first case, and the motion above described added at the later date."], "other": ["Inv. 1885-121-31,151", "John Maud, chemist and druggist", "Motive Power stationary engine; stationary engine 1797"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Watt Collection"], "dates": ["1800", "1797"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["improvements upon those in the actual engine", "framing is of timber", "supported under the beam gudgeon by a metal column carried on a masonry pedestal", "beam is a casting", "terminal pins carried in trunnion hoops which adjust themselves to any inaccuracy in the erection", "valves are of the drop type, two for each end of the cylinder", "stem of the lower valve passes through the tubular stem of the upper one, rendering only one opening into the steam box necessary while simplifying the mechanism", "valves are driven by a quiet tappet gear from a horizontal shaft rocked by an eccentric on the crank-shaft", "valve gear does not permit of expansive working", "beam is fitted with Watt's parallel motion", "looping of the lower tie rod", "air-pump rod is directly connected with the parallel point, in the way that has since been generally followed", "condenser is cylindrical and is enclosed in a water tank", "top of the condenser is secured the air-pump", "discharge of which is led off by a shoot", "injection water is conveyed to the condenser by a horizontal pipe from outside the tank", "top cover of the air-pump is guided as in No. 78", "steam cylinder is 1.625 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke"], "other": ["No. 75", "Inv. 1876-1254", "S.M. 862", "20,700"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["circa 1800"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A working model of a double-acting beam engine, likely built around 1800. The engine features improvements over the actual engine installed in 1797 (object number 75), including drop valves with a simplified stem mechanism and a tappet gear for valve operation, although it does not support expansive working. The design incorporates Watt's parallel motion and a novel air-pump rod connection. The condenser is water-cooled, and the air pump is mounted on top."], "other": ["https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/objects/co8142011/model-of-a-double-acting-beam-engine-working"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1897"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Drawing of Cartwright's engine. (Scale 1: 8.)", "Rev. Edmund Cartwright, D.D. (Inventor)", "Prepared in the Museum, 1897", "This arrangement, patented in 1797 by the Rev. Edmund Cartwright, D.D., was followed in the construction of several engines of the time.", "Although intended for steam, Cartwright pointed out that the engine might be worked by the vapour of \"ardent spirit or ether.\"", "A single-acting vertical steam cylinder is employed, having its piston-rod carried down to the bucket of the air-pump, which is placed below in an immersed condenser of the surface type formed by enclosing a cylindrical shell within another of larger diameter.", "The piston is forced downward by steam pressure until it nearly reaches the bottom of its stroke, when a spring on the crosshead closes the steam valve; the spindle of an exhaust valve in the piston afterwards strikes the cylinder bottom, and so permits the steam to escape into the condenser, thus allowing the piston to pass again to the top of the cylinder under the action of the fly-wheel.", "The packing of the piston and its rod are stated to have been entirely of metal, and were early examples of metallic packing."], "other": ["Inv. 1897-125", "30,064", "Prepared in the Museum 1797 (Patent date)"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF CARTWRIGHT'S ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["Museum (Maker)", "1902"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1902"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This model shows Cartwright's mechanism for converting the reciprocating motion of the piston into rotary motion.", "The engine itself presented several exceptional features (see No. 94), but the only other one of these followed in this model is that the valve motion is directly derived from that of the piston by a tappet action.", "The arrangement for guiding the end of the piston-rod, in place of the then general parallel motion, comprised a long crosshead secured to the piston-rod and revolving in opposite directions.", "In this way the oblique thrusts of the two connecting rods were caused to neutralise each other, and the piston-rod had only to resist the direct piston effort, which it was able to do without the assistance of a parallel motion or other form of guide.", "This arrangement of mechanism was abandoned for many years, but it is now successfully employed for driving the two revolving prisms in the rotary form of air-pump know as a \"pressure blower\"; in such cases, however, the engine crosshead is also provided with slide guides, as shown in an attached illustration."], "other": ["Scale 1: 10"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TREVITHICK ENGINE AND BOILER"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1881"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["form of high pressure engine which, combined with the return flue boiler, was patented by Trevithick and Vivian in 1802, and subsequently extensively used for locomotives as well as semi-portable engines", "boiler shell is of cast iron 1 in. thick, 3.6 ft. diam., and 5.5 ft. long; the back end, which is dished, is cast with it, while the front of the shell has a flange to which the wrought iron front of the boiler is secured by bolts", "To this front the two ends of the return, or horseshoe, flue are riveted; the larger leg of the flue is 18 in. diam. and holds the grate, the return portion being only 10 in. diam.", "front of the boiler also has a manhole, but the system of construction rendered the whole interior readily accessible for scaling and repairs, owing to the ease with which the boiler front and furnace could be removed", "steam generated passed into a cast-iron steam dome, surmounted by a 2 in. lever-weighted safety-valve, from which it was led by an external pipe to the valve chest of the steam cylinder", "cylinder is arranged vertically, and is steam jacketed, being almost immersed in the boiler to which it is secured by an upper flange", "boiler steam, after passing through a stop valve of the plug type, is admitted alternately to the two ends of the cylinder by a four-way plug valve worked by a tappet motion", "Trevithick and Vivian patented in 1802", "used for locomotives", "used for semi-portable engines"], "other": ["Received (Status)", "Inv. 1881-57-25,244 (Accession number)", "2 in. lever-weighted safety-valve (part description)"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["BEAM ENGINE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M. I."], "dates": ["1907", "1802"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This form of \u201cportable\u201d or self-contained condensing beam engine was brought out in 1805 by Matthew Murray, of Leeds. It proved in practice to be not easily accessible, and only a few engines were therefore made. It is interesting, nevertheless, as having the same general arrangement as the side-lever engine which subsequently became the recognised type for marine purposes. The engine is contained within a tank supported on four feet. A dividing partition enables the cylinder and valve box to be packed with non-conducting material, while the air-pump and condenser are surrounded by water. The cylinder crosshead has two side rods working on to a pin on the end of a beam rocking on a centre on the underside of the tank. The other end of the beam has a connecting rod to a crankshaft above, with a large fly-wheel. The air-pump is worked similarly by side rods from an intermediate point in the beam. Neither cylinder nor air-pump crossheads are guided. Steam is distributed to the cylinder by the \u201clocomotive\u201d slide-valve which had been patented by Murray in 1802. The valve has a rack on the back geared into by a sector which is actuated by a rod having a frame at the other end embracing a cam on the crankshaft; the cam gives a period of rest at the end of each stroke. The injection cock to the condenser can be adjusted by a hand lever moving over an index plate.", "6 h.p.", "cylinder 3 in. diam. by 5 in. stroke."], "other": ["Received 1907", "Inv. 1907-23"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Model of Murray's portable beam engine", "Motive Power model"], "makers": ["James Fox, Derby"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1808"], "places": ["Derby"], "descriptions": ["with metal rod and fitting", "belonging to the exhaust", "model"], "other": ["model 1808 Derby"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODELS OF TABLE ENGINES (working)"], "makers": ["Henry Maudslay"], "organisations/institutions": ["Maudslay Collection"], "dates": ["1900", "1807"], "places": ["Lambeth Works"], "descriptions": ["The original form of this engine, as patented by Henry Maudslay in 1807, is represented by an adjacent drawing, from which these models differ only in detail. Many engines of this kind were made; till the Lambeth Works were closed in 1900, two of them were regularly engaged there in driving some of the machinery. The cylinder is carried vertically on a cast-iron table, beneath which are the crankshaft bearings and the condensing arrangements. The piston-rod passes through the top cover and terminates in a balancing or articulated crosshead carrying a pair of wheels which roll between guides formed in an independent framing secured to the table and the cylinder. From the cross-head there are two connecting rods, which proceed to two independent cranks in the crankshaft below. The steam is distributed by a plug valve rocked by a rod connected with a triangular cam on the crankshaft. The air, cold water, and feed pumps are worked by an inverted T-bob driven by a roller on the intermediate portion of the crankshaft."], "other": ["Scale 1 : 4 and 1 : 24.", "Inv. 1900-23, 25,501, and Inv. 1900-194."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["FACTORY BEAM ENGINE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1830\u201340", "1915"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["small example of the self-contained non-condensing beam engine made about 1830\u201340 for factory purposes.", "The cylinder is 7.25 in. diam. by 14 in. stroke.", "The slide valve is of unusual design, being a hollow box, shaped like a flat inverted U, the legs of which slide on a flat seating joining the cylinder ports and forming the front of the valve chest. Live steam surrounds the valve and passes underneath to the inside edges of the steam ports, while the exhaust takes place through the interior of the valve to a port at the lower end of the valve face which leads to an exit in the base of the cylinder.", "A spring on the back of the valve keeps it to its face when steam is shut off.", "The valve is actuated by an eccentric with a gab-ended rod.", "A butterfly valve throttled by a Watt centrifugal governor controls steam admission to the valve chest.", "The framing and entablature of the engine is in the classical style which was much affected in the early years of the 19th century."], "other": ["Inv. 1915-128"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Joseph Mauds lay", "Joshua Field"], "organisations/institutions": ["Marine Engineering Collection"], "dates": ["1839"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["patented in 1839 The twin-cylinder or \u201cSiamese\u201d engine, patented in 1839 by Joseph Mauds lay and Joshua Field for marine purposes (see Marine Engineering Collection) was modified for land use in exceptional cases, as here shown; the advantage of the arrangement is that a long stroke can be accommodated in a limited height, but mechanically it is undesirable, so that few were made; in common with the \u201ctable\u201d (see No. 103) and other engines of this time it was superseded by the direct-acting type.", "The two cylinders have a common crosshead, which is of a T-shape, working in guides between the cylinders; it is formed of two plates between which swings the connecting rod, whose point of attachment is at the tail of the T while its big end joins to the crankshaft overhead.", "The valve is a simple four-way cock, the lever of which is actuated by an eccentric."], "other": ["Scale about 1: 24", "Inv. 1911-58"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Royal Horticultural Gardens", "Royal Albert Hall"], "dates": ["1840 till 1870"], "places": ["Royal Horticultural Gardens", "Royal Albert Hall"], "descriptions": ["16 in. stroke, and the piston rod is connected to a beam about four times the length of the stroke. The centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles attached to the framing and thus a straight line motion is impressed on the crosshead. The other end of the beam is pivoted on two long rocking links and it is the fancied appearance of these in motion which gave rise to the name of the engine.", "Its duty in both places was to pump water from an artesian well.", "As arranged in the last place the crankshaft was connected by a claw clutch and bevel gearing, in the ratio of 3 : 1, to a three-throw bore hole pump, 9 in. stroke, lifting from a depth of about 90 ft.", "The steam pressure was 50 lb. by gauge."], "other": ["Inv. 1921-533"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1869"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The grasshopper engine, so named from its peculiar motion (see No. 114), has been known also as the half-beam engine.", "The cylinder is vertical and its piston-rod is connected with a crosshead whence two connecting rods return to a double-throw crankshaft below.", "The crosshead is fixed in one end of the beam, the other end being pivoted on two rocking links; the centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles, half the length of the beam, attached to the framing.", "A straight line motion is thus impressed on the crosshead.", "The air-pump is attached to the \u201cparallel\u201d point in an extra parallelogram obtained from the centre of the beam.", "A plunger and a bucket-pump are driven directly from the beam.", "Steam is distributed by a piston valve actuated by a countershaft which is driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft.", "A Watt governor controls the throttle valve.", "The hand-wheels for controlling the engine are grouped on a platform.", "working"], "other": ["1: 12", "Inv. 1869-63, 19,278"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DRAWING OF MCNAUGHTED BEAM ENGINE"], "makers": ["Petrie & McNaught"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1923", "early part of the 19th century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 16", "In many factories, where the then standard beam engine had been installed during the early part of the 19th century, the need for greater power was experienced as time went on. In 1845 Mr. John McNaught patented a means of meeting this need with a minimum of expense. He compounded the existing engine by the addition of a high-pressure cylinder at the other end of the beam between the gudgeons and the crankshaft. This was usually possible because existing scantling was generally capable of sustaining the additional stress involved. The practice, admittedly a stop-gap, was known as \u201cMcNaughting\u201d and was extensively followed.", "In the drawing the added parts are indicated by thickened lines."], "other": ["Inv. 1923-535"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DOUBLE-CYLINDER ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["Messrs. John Musgrave and Sons, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["Messrs. John Musgrave and Sons, Ltd."], "dates": ["1893"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a small example of an engine differing only slightly from the preceding (Nos. 113 and 126).", "Two cylinders, arranged side by side, have a common connecting-rod in the form of a triangle, the apex of which encloses the pin of the overhanging crank.", "The two other corners of the triangle are, by very short links, connected respectively with the two piston-rods, the crossheads of which slide in ordinary guides.", "From the middle of the top of the triangle two bridle-rods couple the connecting-rod to a stationary centre on the side of the framing, and so restrict the movement and close the chain.", "The valves are in the form of cylindrical slides, and receive their motion from a common eccentric.", "The example has 3 in. cylinders, with 4 in. stroke, and is intended to run at 300 r.p.m., when it will indicate about 3 h.p."], "other": ["Inv. 1893-176", "19,602"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["VERTICAL STEAM ENGINE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1913"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["compact form of direct-acting engine in which a connecting-rod is dispensed with, the piston-rod being directly connected with the crankpin by a block sliding in a transverse slot formed in the crosshead.", "arrangement is sometimes known as a \"dog-crank\"", "much used for feed pumps.", "cylinder is 4 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke", "placed vertically on a bedplate which also serves as the bottom cover.", "crosshead is very wide, above the cylinder in bearings cast on the top cover.", "crosshead is very wide, and is formed of two gunmetal bars bolted together with distance pieces between their ends, the latter also acting as slipper blocks, which slide on two round guide bars rising from the bedplate and tied together at the top.", "steel block, made in halves, embraces the crankpin and fits in the crosshead slot, so that as the crank revolves the block slides along the slot through a distance equal to the stroke of the crank.", "arrangement allows the engine to be very short, but it introduces large bending stresses in the piston-rod, which is, therefore, made of large diameter.", "arrangement is equivalent to a connecting-rod of infinite length, and the piston has a simple harmonic motion.", "ordinary slide-valve is used, operated by a disc crank on one end of the shaft, and a fly-wheel is mounted on the other end of the shaft."], "other": ["Inv. 1913-304", "S.M. 560", "4 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke"]}
