Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This represents a high-pressure engine, with a steam-jacketed cylinder supported throughout its length on a cast-iron bed.", "The guides are cast with the bed and bored out, the crankpin is attached to an overhanging crankplate and the outer end of the crankshaft is carried by an independent bearing.", "The engine is fitted with a governor gear that automatically adjusts the degree of expansion to the work being done.", "On the crankshaft are three eccentrics, but one of these is solely used for working the feed pump.", "The others drive the main slide-valve and the \"back cut-off\" or expansion-valve.", "The travel of the expansion-valve is determined by the position of a block in a rocking link, and this position is adjusted by the governor.", "When the governor rises it rotates the sheave of a small eccentric connected with it, and by this means moves the block along the link; as an eccentric is a non-reversible means of transmitting motion it is here introduced to prevent pressure from the link interfering with the action of the governor."], "other": ["1 : 4", "The cylinder is 12.25 in. diam. by 22 in. stroke ; when the engine is supplied with steam at 60 lb. pressure and is making 95 r.p.m., it indicates 50 h.p.", "the same design was followed for engines with cylinders up to 22 in. diam. by 40 in. stroke indicating 185 h.p.", "Inv. 1885-123, 19,274 and 19,366"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["high-speed horizontal engine of American design", "cylinder, which is 5 in. diam. by 7 in. stroke, is overhung", "externally by polished metal lagging covering the flanges as well as the usual non-conducting felt", "crank is formed with two counterbalanced discs", "two fly-wheels", "crankshaft has exceptionally long bearings", "crank race is, moreover, enclosed by a cast-iron box, which retains any oil thrown off, and also carries the crankpin lubricator", "slide valve is of the piston type, with the steam space in the middle, as was usual in the early long D valves", "driven, through a rocking shaft, by an eccentric of variable throw within one of the fly-wheels", "governor, which is arranged within this fly-wheel, consists of two heavy swinging levers pinned to opposite arms of the fly-wheel, and pulled inward by helical springs", "When the levers swing outward, through centrifugal action, they turn the main eccentric and also an eccentric carrying it, moving them in opposite directions, so that the main eccentric is shifted along an approximately straight line, the cut-off being thereby altered while the lead remains nearly constant"], "other": ["Inv. 1888-236"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SECTIONAL MODEL OF HIGH-SPEED ENGINE (working)", "SECTIONAL MODEL OF HIGH-SPEED ENGINE"], "makers": ["Mr. N. Chandler"], "organisations/institutions": ["Pumps Section"], "dates": ["1886-8", "1886", "1888"], "places": ["Wednesfield, Staffordshire"], "descriptions": ["This represents a single-acting, inverted, two-stage expansion engine for directly driving a large fan for mine ventilation (see Pumps Section), or other purposes.", "the two cylinders are arranged tandem fashion, with the high pressure above, so that there is a single piston-rod acting downward upon a crankshaft below, while the steam distribution is performed by two piston-valves similarly arranged and driven by a single eccentric.", "The cylinders are cast on a frame which contains guides for the piston and valve-rods, and the bearings for the crankshaft; it also forms a closed chamber in which the oil is retained and distributed over the bearings by the motion of the revolving parts, access to it being, however, obtainable by side doors.", "A special feature of this engine is the construction of the \"sleeve\" at the lower end of the valve, by which, while permitting the passage of the exhaust steam through itself, the valve can close the exhaust port, thus giving comparatively quietly the momentum of the moving parts and assist them on their return stroke.", "The action of the steam in the engine is as follows:\u2014Boiler steam is admitted above the high-pressure piston, which then makes a down stroke; in the next up stroke this steam is allowed to pass to the under side of the high-pressure piston and into a receiver, from which, in the next down stroke, it is admitted to the top side of the low-pressure piston; from this, at about the completion of this down stroke, it is discharged into the exhaust pipe, or condenser, with which the lower side of the piston is in communication, except when the cushioning at the end of the stroke is taking place.", "for mine ventilation"], "other": ["Inv. 1902-130", "Received 1902"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Corliss valve gear"], "makers": ["G. H. Corliss"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1849", "1867"], "places": ["Paris"], "descriptions": ["The valve gear is of the \u201cCorliss\u201d type, and under the control of the governor; it alters the degree of expansion to meet variations in the load, without the intervention of any throttle-valve, and as usually set the speed does not vary more than 2.5 per cent. from no load to full load.", "The adjacent diagram shows how the point of \u201ccut-off\u201d changes with the slight alteration in the governor speeds.", "not being an engineer he experienced exceptional difficulty in getting his invention tried, but the results obtained with it ultimately led to its very extensive adoption", "the first Corliss engine in Europe was that shown at the Paris Exhibition in 1867.", "the leading features of the arrangement are: the employment of separate steam and exhaust valves at each end of the cylinder, so that any alteration of the point at which steam is cut off can be made without interfering with the action of the exhaust valves; the valves are cylindrical, and each is capable of being separately adjusted.", "The two exhaust valves, which are at the bottom of the cylinder, are rocked by a single eccentric, while the two steam-valves at the top are rocked by another eccentric.", "The steam eccentric swings an arm provided with a cylindrical end, upon which are two hardened steel plates; as the arm swings, these plates engage with similar plates attached to flat levers that proceed from cranks on the spindles of the two steam-valves.", "As the arm reciprocates, the steam-valves are alternately opened, but, at certain points, determined by the speed of the governor, the lever of the steam-valve then opening slips off the corresponding driving plate; the valve then left free is rapidly turned into a closed position by the action of a helical spring.", "The spring is contained in a small cylinder provided with two air \u201cdash-pots\u201d by which the quick closing motion is quietly arrested; this sharp and automatically adjusted cut-off is now to be found in all modern \u201ctrip\u201d gears.", "The governor shown is of the high speed loaded type, and has its sensitiveness adjustable by means of a spring which is contained within the central weight; it is driven by three cotton ropes, but further to reduce the risk of the engine running away through the governor stopping, an independent gear is fitted, so that if, after the engine has been started, the speed of the governor falls below a certain limit, a trigger releases a weighted lever which automatically stops the engine through its valve gear."], "other": ["Inv. 1898-39", "20,684", "20,693"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF SEMI-PORTABLE OVERTYPE ENGINE (working)"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group database", "Power Transmission Section"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 8", "This represents a type of engine and boiler largely used in difficult situations owing to the fact that it is easily transported and needs practically no foundations.", "The boiler is of the locomotive type, the chief feature of which is the staying of the fire-box (not visible in the model).", "Instead of the roof stays being supported as usual on the front and the tube plates, they rest on angles riveted inside the outer shell, thus relieving the fire-box of crushing stress; in addition more room for cleaning the crown of the fire-box is given.", "The top and sides of the fire-box are each one steel plate, planed, drilled in position and riveted hydraulically.", "The fire-box is mounted on channels forming an ashpan, and at the smoke-box end of the boiler the support is a circular pedestal, made to act as a feed tank.", "The cylinder is bolted to steel flanged seatings riveted to the boiler and is tied to the crankshaft bearings, similarly supported with provision for expansion, by steel stay rods which support the spectacle plate.", "The valve gear consists of a single eccentric bolted to a slotted disc graduated so that the point of cut-off can be varied from 0.125 to 0.375 with constant lead, and, if necessary, moved over to reverse the direction of rotation.", "If the engine were required to be frequently reversed, a link motion would be fitted.", "The governor is of high-speed type controlling an equilibrium valve.", "Mechanical lubrication is adopted.", "At the scale indicated above, the model represents an engine with cylinder 12 in. diam. by 16 in. stroke; flywheel 66 in. diam. by 11 in. wide; the engine develops 30\u201345 h.p. at 120 r.p.m.", "A number of other sizes and classes of this engine, besides portable and undertype engines (see Power Transmission Section) are made."], "other": ["Inv. 1920-63", "S.M. 1,226", "working", "working"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DRAWING OF WATT'S SEMI-ROTARY ENGINE"], "makers": ["Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1897", "1782"], "places": ["Heathfield"], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 16", "Prepared in the Museum", "copied from Watt's patent specification", "unfinished model of this engine, which was commenced in 1765 or 1766", "short horizontal cylinder with a radial piston which can swing through an arc of 240 deg", "lower sector of the cylinder is fitted with a stationary abutment block through which steam is admitted to either side of the piston alternately. Below the cylinders are valve boxes for the distribution of the steam, while beneath these is a jet condenser, and two air pumps which are driven by racks from a pinion on the vibrating shaft. A large spur wheel on this shaft has two racks gearing with it, and these move the rods of the two pit pumps that the engine was designed to work; by this latter arrangement the pump rods mutually counterbalance."], "other": ["1897-122", "21,053", "Inv."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["James Watt's Rotary and Semi-Rotary Engines"], "makers": ["James Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group", "Science Museum"], "dates": ["1782"], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power drawing"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["DRAWING OF WATT'S ROTARY ENGINE, WITH CONDENSER.", "Scale 1: 16.", "This is copied from the 1782 patent specification of James Watt, but there is no evidence that he ever constructed such an engine.", "The drawing shows a piston in the form of a closely-fitting radial arm projecting from an axial shaft in a cylinder. An abutment, arranged as a flap, is hinged, near a recess in the side of the cylinder, and swings while remaining in contact with the piston. Steam is admitted to the chamber on one side of the flap, and so causes an unbalanced pressure upon the radial arm.", "The arrangement has been re-invented several times, and has been worked out in a practical form (see No. 142)."], "other": ["Prepared in the Museum.", "Inv. 1897-122, 21,053."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF A ROTARY ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["Rev. Patrick Bell, LL.D."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1868"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This engine shows one of the early attempts to obtain rotary motion from the pressure of steam without the intervention of a crank and connecting-rod", "almost the same arrangement was proposed in 1838 by Lord Armstrong as a water motor, and an example subsequently constructed gave off 5 h.p. at 30 r.p.m., with an efficiency of 95 per cent.", "A metal disc is secured to a horizontal axis carried in bearings, and the lower half of the disc is enclosed by a chamber of circular section having its axis a semi-circle.", "One end of this chamber is closed and provided with a pipe through which steam enters, the exhaust taking place through the open end.", "The disc is provided with three holes, each fitted with a circular plate turning on an axis radial to the disc, and these plates when set at right angles to the disc become pistons in the lower enclosing chamber.", "The steam pressure upon these pistons forces the disc round, but the engine is non-expansive, and although some provision for packing has been made, the leakage must have been considerable and the wear and tear excessive."], "other": ["Inv. 1868-24", "19,371"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Bell's Rotary Engine", "Patrick Bell's Rotary steam engine"], "makers": ["Bell, Patrick"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["Scotland", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power model", "model steel"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF A DISC ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["R. B. Prosser", "W. Taylor", "H. Davies", "Ransomes and Sims", "G. and J. Rennie"], "organisations/institutions": ["Marine Engineering Collection"], "dates": ["1830", "1841"], "places": ["Liverpool"], "descriptions": ["The disc engine was patented by Messrs. E. and J. Dakeyne in 1830, and subsequently improved by Messrs. W. Taylor and H. Davies, besides others.", "In 1841 Messrs. Ransomes and Sims showed at Liverpool a Dakeyne rotary engine of 5 h.p., the first portable engine on wheels.", "It drove a thrashing machine and was rendered self-propelling by pitch chains from the crankshaft to the travelling axle.", "A similar engine was applied with some success by Messrs. G. and J. Rennie to drive a screw propeller", "more recently the arrangement has been extensively used as a water meter.", "The chamber, which acts as a cylinder, is enclosed laterally by a spherical zone and endwise by a pair of cones whose apexes come together. The piston is a circular disc fitting the interior of the zone round its edge, and having at its centre a ball which forms the joint on which it gyrates. From the ball, and perpendicular to the disc, projects a rod whose further end is socketed in a crank arm attached to the shaft to be driven. There is a fixed radial partition in the cylinder, and a corresponding slot in the disc permits of the requisite motion. The disc and partition divide the chamber into four spaces, two of which are expanding while the other two are contracting; steam is admitted into the former and discharged from the latter by ports formed through the spherical wall of the partition, and the disc itself, by its motion over them, performs the function of a valve. The engine may be reversed by interchanging the inlet and exhaust passages."], "other": ["Inv. 1893-172", "21,068"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Hick's Rotary engine"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["casing at one place. At one side of this line of contact is the port or passage for the admission of steam, and at the other side of it is the exhaust port. The inner ends of the blades are free to turn on a stud fixed centrally with the casing, and the exposed surface of these blades between the drum and the casing form pistons upon which the steam acts, and so causes them to revolve and carry round the drum."], "other": ["Inv. 1895-149", "Maudsley Collection"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["John Hick's Rotary engine"], "makers": ["John Hick"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum"], "dates": ["1843"], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Working model in metal", "Motive Power model"], "other": ["model 1895"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODELS OF ROTARY ENGINE"], "makers": ["John Trotter"], "organisations/institutions": ["Maudslay Collection"], "dates": ["1805", "1852"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["These wooden models represent the rotary engine patented by Joseph Maudsley in 1852; the same thing had, however, been patented by John Trotter in 1805.", "The engine consists essentially of a rotating cylindrical chamber, within which rotates a smaller cylindrical chamber placed eccentrically so as to touch the first.", "The inner chamber has a slot at one point, through which projects a radial partition fixed to the outer chamber; the crescent-shaped space between the two chambers is thus divided into two parts, one of which is expanding while the other is contracting, as the chambers revolve.", "Steam being admitted through a port in the outer chamber causes an unbalanced pressure upon the partition, the opposite side of which is connected with the exhaust by a port in the inner chamber, and so drives the chambers round.", "One model has the two chambers surrounded by a concentric casing to which the steam is admitted, the exhaust being through the axis.", "The other model is double and has three concentric rings with radial partitions between them, forming two chambers in which two eccentric rings rotate; no steam ports are shown on this model."], "other": ["Inv. 1900-22"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Two models in wood of Maudslay's rotary engine"], "makers": ["Maudslay, Sons and Field Limited"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["c1852"], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power model"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1889 and 1894"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A complete 6 in. engine, together with a wooden model, are shown, which illustrate the mode of action of the engine patented by Mr. Beauchamp Tower in 1879, and now known as the \u201cspherical\u201d engine because the working chamber is a complete sphere.", "The mechanism is equivalent to a universal joint connecting two shafts inclined together at an angle of 135 deg.", "The cross-piece of the joint is filled in so as to form a circular piston, and the jaws or bows of the joint are filled in solid to the shape of a quarter of a sphere.", "The whole joint is enclosed in a spherical chamber, and it will be seen that the disc alternately approaches and recedes from the spherical segments to which it is attached, as the shafts rotate.", "Throughout each revolution there are two cavities simultaneously opening, and two closing\u2014all four varying at the same mean rate, so that if steam is admitted into the enlarging cavities, and be permitted to exhaust from those that are closing, continuous rotation of the shafts is obtained.", "The rotation of the segments upon the surface of the sphere is utilised to distribute the steam\u2014ports in the spherical surface being uncovered at the correct intervals by the moving segments.", "The chambers obtained in this engine are each equal to a quarter of the volume of the sphere, and in one revolution the total volume passed is equal to that of the sphere.", "As the only reciprocation is that due to the swing of the disc, the engine is suited for high speeds, and, for the power given off, is very compact."], "other": ["Inv. 1889-76", "Inv. 1894-275", "21,060"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1879"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Motive Power model; model"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["rotary engine"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["On the revolution of the shafts the pistons reciprocate in their cylinders in much the same way as in an ordinary engine, and the valve arrangement is such that while each piston is receding from its cylinder the steam pressure is driving it, and during the in-stroke of each, its cylinder is in communica- tion with the exhaust. There are thus four single-acting cylinders making each a double stroke for one revolution of the driving-shaft. The engine has no dead centres, and has been run at 1,000 r.p.m."], "other": ["Inv. 1888-183", "21,061"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1892", "1885", "1885"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["working", "This machine, patented in 1885 by Mr. A. Rigg, will be found to resemble in its movements an oscillating cylinder engine held by its crankshaft, and performing its cycle by the revolution of the framing round the crankshaft and the cylinder round the crankpin.", "The varying chamber of a reciprocating engine is thus obtained, while the inertia stresses due to the reciprocating parts are almost eliminated.", "The engine has three single-acting cylinders, the long plunger pistons of which act outwardly upon three crankpins, projecting from the face of an overhanging fly-wheel.", "The closed end of each cylinder is formed into an eye, and fits upon a stud or trunnion fixed to the engine-bed.", "This stud is not on the same centre-line as the fly-wheel shaft, so that in a complete revolution each piston makes a double stroke, of a length equal to twice this eccentricity.", "The driving stud acts on a sliding block so that the eccentricity can be varied and the stroke of the engine is rendered adjustable.", "The engine is reversed by sliding the stud into line with the fly-wheel shaft and continuing the sliding so as to give the eccentricity on the opposite side.", "The passage of the working fluid to and from the cylinders takes place through the faces of the eyes at the cylinder ends, which are provided with ports.", "The fluid enters and leaves the engine by the block carrying the stationary stud, the face of the block forming a surface on which the nearest cylinder end revolves, and acting as a disc slide-valve for the three cylinders.", "An adjacent sectional drawing shows clearly the details of this arrangement.", "The engine can be worked by steam, air, or water, but the full advantage resulting from the variable stroke is only obtained when working with water, owing to the cylinder clearance increasing as the stroke is reduced.", "The ordinary speed of these engines is from 100 to 500 r.p.m. with water pressure of 750 lb. per sq. in.", "When steam or compressed air is used, as many as 2,000 r.p.m. have been obtained."], "other": ["Mr. A. Rigg", "Inv. 1892-74, 19,372"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["exhausting the steam as the ports pass the packing strips."], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The cylinder ends are made steam tight in the casing by cast-iron rings rotating with it and fitting between two non-rotating gunmetal rings, the outer one of which is adjusted by set-screws passing through the casing cover and pressing on a cast-iron backing ring.", "The longitudinal packings are pressed inward by springs and adjusted by external nuts.", "The bearings have short steel rollers of large diameter which are prevented from winding by closely-fitting side plates; the rollers run on hardened steel rings.", "Such engines could be made to reverse by providing the casing with two sets of inlet and exhaust ports, and suitable valves for bringing either set into use.", "This example has a steam inlet of 1\u00b719 in. diam., and a piston 6 in. long; it was designed to develop 20 to 30 h.p."], "other": ["Inv.", "1911-14", "steam"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1890"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is the original steam turbine, made in 1884.", "It worked for several years driving the dynamo which gave off 5 electrical h.p.", "The motor consists of a series of parallel-flow turbines on the same shaft, the first being the supply for the second, and so on. By this arrangement the efficient action of a steam turbine is greatly reduced.", "To allow for the increased volume of the steam as its pressure falls in passing through the machines, the proportions of the turbines alter as the final one is approached, the passages being enlarged and the pitch of the blades increased.", "A set of guide blades, with its corresponding rotating ring, forming one element of a later turbine, is shown separately beside the machine.", "End thrust is obviated by employing two equal series of turbines on the same spindle on each side of the central steam inlet, the exhaust taking place from each end equally.", "By this arrangement also, glands are avoided as the slight leakage through the bearings under the exhaust pressure is easily collected and occasions no loss.", "To prevent vibration the bearings throughout are not quite rigidly fixed to the main castings, but are permitted a slight movement between clamping washers, the alternate washers fitting the casting and clearing the outside of the bearing, and *vice versa*.", "The lubrication of the bearings is effected by a current of oil continually circulated by a small screw pump formed on the main shaft.", "In its course the oil passes through the hollow shaft of the dynamo so that it shall assist in cooling the armature and commutator.", "The governing is performed by a cylindrical throttle-valve actuated by a leather diaphragm, on one side of which the air pressure is reduced by a kind of fan attached to the main shaft.", "The exhausting action of the fan is partially neutralised by an iron arm turning on a vertical axis, by the attraction of the field magnet, drawn round, against the action of a spring, into a position that causes its extremity nearly to close the entrance to the air-pipe.", "By this arrangement the opening of the throttle-valve is regulated by the centrifugal action of the fan and by the intensity of the magnetic field, the control being partly mechanical and partly electrical.", "The dynamo has a drum armature, but, owing to the high speed employed, only a few convolutions are required, which, being of large section, give a very low internal resistance.", "The commutator is built up of short gunmetal segments insulated with asbestos and dove-tailed into steel rings.", "The machine is shunt wound."], "other": ["Inv. 1890-59", Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF STEAM TURBINE (working)"], "makers": ["Made in the Museum"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1909"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a working model illustrating the principle and arrangement of the compound reaction turbine of the Parsons type (see Nos. 151 and 155). It consists of a revolving drum upon which are mounted two rings of curved blades; two rings of similar blades are fixed to the casing and alternate with them, and the steam passes from the inlet end between the fixed and moving sets of blades alternately, while expanding. This arrangement of turbines in series reduces the steam and blade velocities, approximately inversely as the square of the number of rings of moving blades. In the model the casing is made of glass so that the blades may be seen."], "other": ["Inv. 1909-35"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Curtis type"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This drawing shows the internal construction of the form of steam turbine in which the high-pressure steam is first expanded in nozzles and passed through a compound impulse wheel of the Curtis type (see No. 157) and then further expanded through a series of rows of blades of the ordinary Parsons reaction type.", "This form was introduced about 1902 (see No. 159), and is much favoured on the Continent; it reduces considerably the length of the machine, and relieves the main casing of the influence of very short high-pressure blades, and of the high pressure and temperature.", "The turbine has a solid forged steel rotor carrying 30 rows of reaction blading, while at the high-pressure end a large disc, which carries two rows of impulse blades, is bolted on.", "The nozzles are attached to a cast steel steam chest bolted to the main casing.", "The steam thrust is balanced by leading steam from the middle of the casing to the large end of the low-pressure drum.", "The shaft runs in brass bearings surrounded by sleeves fitted in cylindrical cast-iron housings, which are themselves mounted in the main bearing casings.", "A thrust and adjusting block is placed at the end of the shaft and is adjusted by sliding the bearing cap.", "SECTIONAL DRAWING OF 500 K.W. COMBINED STEAM TURBINE.", "compound impulse wheel", "ordinary Parsons reaction type"], "other": ["Scale 1: 4.", "No. 157", "No. 159"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["steel drum with three diameters, and has 64 rows of moving blades varying in length from 2.75 in. to 6.5 in. Balance drums are provided at the high-pressure end, and the bladed portion is nearly 12 ft. long and 65 in. maximum diam. Loads exceeding 20,000 k.w. are provided for by a by-pass-valve, which admits steam directly to the twentieth row of blades. The steam passes from the high-pressure casing through two pipes, 30 in. diam., to a central chamber surrounding the low-pressure turbine, which is double ended. The low-pressure rotor is a cylinder, 14.5 ft. long, mounted on a central spider, and two expansion diaphragms on each side of the casing; it has 24 rows of moving blades 2.75 in. to 19 in. long. The condenser, which has a cooling surface of 39,600 sq. ft., is suspended below the low-pressure casing, but a large proportion of the weight is borne by spring supports beneath it. Very complete governing gear is fitted, comprising a relay-operated main-valve, an emergency stop-valve, and an automatic overload bypass-valve. The turbine shaft is connected with the alternator shaft by a flexible claw coupling. The turbine runs at 750 rev. per min., and uses steam at a pressure of 200 lb. per sq. in., superheated 200\u00b0 F., and a vacuum of 29 in. The guaranteed steam consumption at 20,000 k.w. was 11.25 lb. per k.w. hour, which is equivalent to 8.1 lb. per shaft h.p. hour. The overall dimensions of the complete machine are 76 ft. long, 18 ft. wide, and 30 ft. high, but 20 ft. of the latter is below the floor level."], "makers": ["C.A. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["BRUSH-LJUNGSTR\u00d6M STEAM TURBINE", "radial flow reaction turbine"], "makers": ["Mr. Birger Ljungstr\u00f6m"], "organisations/institutions": ["Brush Electrical Engineering Co.", "Engineering"], "dates": ["1915", "1906", "1879"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["prints show improvements in the steam turbine patented", "system of fixed and moving blades, both sets of blades revolve in opposite directions and power is taken off both shafts, consequently for the same relative speed, the shafts need only revolve at half the speed of the older systems.", "consists of a series of concentric blade rings, mounted on two discs, each turbine rotor being fixed to short hollow extension shafts, so that each disc is overhung from the end of its alternator shaft.", "blade rings interchange, the blades being set in opposite directions; Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF BEAM ENGINE FRAME"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Watt Collection"], "dates": ["1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This shows a complete timber framing for a beam engine and represents the practice of Boulton and Watt about 1795.", "It consists of two rectangular frames slightly inclined together at the top, and with the upper horizontal members supported under the bearings of the engine beam by two inclined struts.", "The main bearing for the crankshaft is carried by an independent trestle similarly supported, and connected with the main framing."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1247", "S.M. 821"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["EXPERIMENTAL BEAMS"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["These models were probably made by Watt when designing beams for his steam engines, as there is evidence that at first the engine beams gave trouble through their insufficient strength and rigidity.", "The smaller beams have parallel top and bottom booms, with diagonal timber struts inclined at 60 deg.; in one case the tie bolts are inclined, and run axially through the timber struts, while in the other vertical iron tie bolts are used.", "In the latter case the model has been loaded to destruction.", "The two larger beams consist each of a lower timber beam with a built-up truss above, the chief difference between them being that in one all the members are in duplicate.", "They have gudgeons and hooks or staples attached by which their strengths could be experimentally determined.", "From their trussing it is evident that these beams were designed for single-acting engines.", "timber struts inclined at 60 deg."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1246", "818 to 820"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Sun and Planet Gear"], "makers": ["Watt (Implied)"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1781"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This and the four succeeding models show some of these mechanisms which he patented in 1781; of these, however, only the sun and planet gear came into use. It is an epicyclic gear consisting of a \"sun\" wheel keyed on the end of the fly-wheel shaft and a \"planet\" wheel bolted to the connecting-rod end and held in gear with the sun wheel by a link loose on their centres, as in the model, or by a pin in the centre of the planet wheel moving in an annular slot. When both wheels are of the same diameter the fly-wheel makes twice the number of revolutions that it would if actuated by a crank and connecting-rod, the extra revolution being due to the fact that the planet wheel, although going round in a circle, does not revolve on its own axis. In some of Watt\u2019s engines the diameter of the planet wheel was less than that of the sun wheel, and in this way shaft speeds were obtained only about 50 per cent. greater than would have been the case with a simple crank."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1258", "17,872", "19,272"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Sun and Planet Gearing"], "makers": ["James Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["James Watt & Co."], "dates": ["1782-1784"], "places": ["England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["demonstrating the action designed to produce a rotative motion.", "Motive Power models", "gears", "epicyclic gearing", "models", "gears", "epicyclic gearing"], "other": ["Preserved by"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1871"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This model shows another of the mechanisms schemed by James Watt about 1781 as an equivalent for the crank.", "The end of the connecting-rod is made in the form of a rack or ladder, the rungs of which are capable of acting on either side of a pinion fixed on the fly-wheel shaft of the engine.", "The connecting-rod is guided by a roller at the lower end, which works in a large opening of special form in a fixed guide plate which keeps the rack in gear with the pinion on the fly-wheel shaft.", "The arrangement somewhat resembles the mangle-wheel motion reversed."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1238", "Collection", "model"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This shows another of the mechanisms patented in 1781 by James Watt as an equivalent of the crank. A connecting rod from the engine beam rocks an equal-armed lever having two conical rollers mounted on it, one at either end. The centre on which the lever moves is close to a vertical shaft on which are mounted a crown cam of considerable throw and a heavy fly-wheel. By the reciprocation of the engine beam, the conical rollers are caused to press upwards alternately against the edge of the crown cam and through the inclined action cause it to rotate. The fly-wheel is for the purpose of carrying the cam over its dead centres. A spur pinion on the fly-wheel shaft gears into a large spur wheel formed on the winding drum."], "other": ["1876", "Watt 1876 (Collection)", "Inv. 1876-1265"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["CYLINDER DRAIN AND RELIEF VALVE"], "makers": ["H. P. Holt, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1879", "1878", "1879-7"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This arrangement of valve, patented by Mr. Holt in 1878, combines in one fitting the drainage and relief safety valves for both ends of an engine cylinder. Pipes from the two ends enter the casing shown, and the discharged water from the cylinder is carried off by a central pipe. In the casing is a valve for each end of the cylinder, and each of these valves consists of a central disc or drain valve, and also of a double-seated annular valve outside, which is the relief valve; these annular valves are kept on their seats by springs. The action is such that, when steam is in one end of the cylinder, its pressure opens the drain valve of the other end or exhaust side, while, at any time, the central or relief portion of the valve will open should the pressure, through priming, exceed the limit determined by the springs."], "other": ["Inv. 1879-7"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DRAWING OF AN INTERMEDIATE RECEIVER", "Cowper\u2019s hot-pot"], "makers": ["E. A. Cowper, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1887", "1857", "1862"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["a steam-jacketed vessel, commonly called \u201cCowper\u2019s hot-pot,\u201d for receiving the steam after it has been used and expanded in the high-pressure cylinder of a compound engine, and before it passes to the low-pressure cylinder: then, when the cranks have moved 90 deg., the steam passes out to the low-pressure cylinder, and in doing so is obliged to pass outside a lining and in close contact with the hot steam-jacketed vessel, thus becoming somewhat warmed up; it is then used and expanded in the low-pressure cylinder, thus allowing of a large amount of expansion and consequent economy.", "The cranks are placed at 90 deg., and the steam is cut off before half stroke in the low-pressure cylinder so that a second charge of steam is not allowed to enter it in the middle of the stroke.", "The receiver was first introduced in 1857", "the internal lining was added in 1862", "This is a steam-jacketed vessel"], "other": ["Inv. 1887-80"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SECTIONAL MODELS OF STEAM ENGINE SLIDE VALVES (working)"], "makers": ["Made in the Museum"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1902"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This series of eight models shows various modifications that have been employed in this type of valve since its original introduction at the end of the 18th century, chiefly in models of an oscillating engine and a steam carriage (see No. 96 and Land Transport Section).", "As a sliding valve may continue its movement after it has closed any particular passage which it controls, it may be so arranged as to open or close other passages, simultaneously or otherwise, and thus combine the duties of several valves.", "Owing to this feature a single slide valve replaced the four beat valves which were originally necessary in the early double-acting steam engines, and this simplicity, combined with quietness in working, has since led to the general adoption of the slide valve in nearly all classes of steam engines.", "The valves illustrated are:\u2014long D, short D, common or locomotive, piston, double-ported, Trick\u2019s, Church\u2019s and Hackworth\u2019s, detailed descriptions of which will be found attached."], "other": ["Inv. 1902-155 to 162, 26,441 to 26,447 & 27,647"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["David Joy"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1900", "1894"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["working", "In this gear (see No. 213) the valve rod is attached to the short end of a long lever, the other end of which is indirectly coupled to the engine connecting rod. The fulcrum of this lever is fitted with a block sliding in a curved guide, and the engine is reversed or \u201clinked-up\u201d by altering the angle that this guide makes with the valve rod. The guide is shaped to a circular arc of a radius equal to the length of the valve rod, and the block, when the engine is running, works equally on both sides of the centre of this guide. As the crankshaft rotates, any point on the connecting rod has a nearly elliptical path, which would give an unequal distribution of the steam at the two ends of the cylinder if the long lever were retained at the one connecting rod. To avoid this objection the motion is obtained from a link, one end of which is attached to the connecting rod and the other to a radius rod. A point in this link describes an oval path, which gives a symmetrical motion to the slide valve.", "It is stated that, in mid-gear, steam is admitted into the cylinder to the extent of the lead at each end, and that the lead is constant for all positions, while unequal lead can be arranged for, if preferred.", "A valuable feature of this gear is that it readily brings the valve chest into a position at right angles to that usually occupied.", "For the sliding block and a curved guide, a swinging lever is sometimes substituted, the inclination of the curved path or the inclination of the swinging lever being altered by changing the position of the stationary end of the lever.", "Photographs of several varieties of engines so fitted will be found in the collection."], "other": ["No. 213", "19,247"]}

Morton; it is shown fitted to a vertical marine engine.", "A radius rod, controls the free end of a lever, which receives a compound motion from the connecting rod and the cross-head.", "From a point in this lever a rod extends to a pin in a curved slot, rigidly attached to the slide valve; the position of the pin in this slot determines whether the engine is in forward or backward gear, and also the grade of expansion.", "The rod from which the valve is directly operated describes a nearly elliptical path, with the major axis horizontal, and so gives a very uniform distribution at both ends of the cylinder."], "other": ["(Scale 1:4.)", "Inv. 1889-77, 19,370."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MOTION DIAGRAM OF AUTOMATIC EXPANSION GEAR"], "makers": ["Messrs. H. & T. C. Batchelor"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1889"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This valve gear, patented in 1882 and 1884, by Mr. C. J. Galloway and Mr. J. H. Beckwith, is intended for use in an engine having an independent exhaust valve and two separate steam valves driven by separate eccentrics.", "The diagram shows the eccentric and gear for one of the steam valves.", "The slide valve rod is moved a certain distance from the eccentric until a catch liberates the valve rod, when it shoots back to the closed position under the action of a spring or piston, a dash-pot being added to stop the valve quietly after the port has been covered.", "The proportion of the piston stroke that is performed before the catch is liberated is determined by the engine governor.", "The motion from the eccentric is transmitted to the valve rod by a short horizontal lever, which when slightly lowered, catches a projection on the valve rod.", "The lever has a roller connected with it rolling on a fixed incline, the amount that the roller is below the lever being determined by the speed of the governor, so that the distance rolled up the incline before the lever is lifted high enough to release the valve rod and so cut off the steam, is automatically controlled.", "A photograph of an engine so fitted is also shown."], "other": ["Inv. 1889-72"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MOTION DIAGRAM OF AUTOMATIC EXPANSION GEAR"], "makers": ["Messrs. H. & T. C. Holborow.", "In the steam chest is a main slide valve, worked by a single eccentric, and on its back is a gridiron cut-off plate worked by another eccentric; the motion of this cut-off valve is controlled by a Porter governor in such a way that the proportion of the stroke done under full steam is decreased upon there being any increase in the speed of the engine.", "The expansion eccentric rocks a link, one end of which is carried by a pin moving with the main valve, and the cut-off valve rod has also a slotted link; into these two slots passes a block connected with the governor, which, by altering the position of the block, determines the amount of relative motion which the back plate receives from its eccentric and thus determines the point of cut-off; the opening and closing of the main slide valve, remain unaltered."], "other": ["Inv. 1886-230"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["D. Halpin, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1901"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this valve motion by Mr. Halpin, there is a single slide valve and two eccentrics; one eccentric gives a simple reciprocating motion that controls the exhaust, while the other rocks a bellcrank lever, which rocks another bellcrank lever connected with the slide valve in such a way that it gives a vibrating motion to the slide valve. The outer lips of the valve have a curved outline, so that any alteration in the angular position alters the lap; to make the arrangement more compact, the curve is made in two portions. The point of cut-off is altered by a governor."], "other": ["Inv. 1894-139"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["HIGH-SPEED GOVERNOR"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1887"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a form of high-speed steam engine governor, designed by Mr. C. T. Porter about 1858, and used very largely for stationary engines. The governor has a pair of arms pivoted at the top of a rotating spindle, and carrying small balls at their lower ends; two links connect the balls to a sliding sleeve, and this is loaded with a large central weight which tends to pull down the balls without increasing their centrifugal action. The sleeve is connected with the throttle valve by levers and rods. This, and other forms of governors running at high speeds, can be made as sensitive as desired, and are more powerful than the older forms, having large balls running at low speeds (see Nos. 73 and 75)."], "other": ["Inv. 1887-252"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["BUSS GOVERNOR"], "makers": ["Messrs. Sch\u00e4ffer & Budenberg", "Messrs. E. and W. Buss"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1888"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this regulator, patented by Messrs. E. and W. Buss in 1870, a hollow vertical spindle, driven from the engine, carries at its upper end a bracket having four arms directed downward. These serve as centres for two swinging frames, each consisting of a horizontal portion, forming an axis, and a vertical arm carrying weights at right angles to one another, the weight on the vertical arm being much smaller than that on the horizontal one, which is on the opposite side of the vertical axis. The frames are directly connected with a crosshead on a sleeve capable of sliding on the spindle and carrying with it an internal rod, which is connected with a throttle valve, arranged below, and controlling the supply of steam to the engine. This construction gives a governor which is in neutral equilibrium at its extreme positions 20 deg. apart, while between these extremes it is very sensitive, but possesses sufficient stability for the purpose of steam engine regulation."], "other": ["Inv. 1888-186"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Bus governor"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1870"], "places": ["London"], "descriptions": ["A bus governor is a device used to automatically control the speed of an engine by regulating the supply of fuel or steam. This particular governor, patented in 1870, operates by using a system of weights and levers to adjust a throttle valve. As the engine speed increases, centrifugal force causes the weights to move outwards, which in turn causes the throttle valve to close, reducing the engine speed. Conversely, as the engine speed decreases, the weights move inwards, opening the throttle valve and increasing the engine speed. This ensures that the engine operates at a relatively constant speed, regardless of changes in load."], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is an example of the form of governor patented by Mr. Scott-Moncrieff in 1872.", "In it a centrifugal pump forces oil into a cylinder containing a loaded piston; an increase of speed increases the oil pressure, so raising the piston and partially closing a throttle valve with which it is connected.", "The governor has a cylindrical chamber with a central diaphragm, one half forming an oil reservoir and the other the pump chamber.", "The oil enters the pump at the centre from the reservoir, and passes into a vertical cylinder cast on one side of the chamber.", "The piston is an easy fit in the cylinder, so that a small quantity of oil leaks past it, and is returned to the reservoir.", "The piston rod passes through a stuffing-box, and is connected with the weighted arm of a pivoted lever, the opposite arm of which is attached to the spindle of a rotating throttle valve.", "The speed is regulated by varying the position of the weight on the lever.", "The pump spindle runs in bearings in the chamber ends, and one end passes through a stuffing-box, and has the driving pulley fixed to it."], "other": ["Inv. 1911-94."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A steam engine governor that uses a centrifugal pump to control speed.", "Its function was to regulate the speed of a steam engine by adjusting a throttle valve.", "The governor is a mechanical device."], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["HIGH-SPEED GOVERNOR"], "makers": ["Sch\u00e4ffer and Budenberg"], "organisations/institutions": ["Messrs. Sch\u00e4ffer and Budenberg"], "dates": ["1888", "1888", "1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a steam engine governor of the form patented by Mr. E. Buss in 1876.", "The mechanism is mounted on a fixed vertical spindle projecting from a casing containing a cylindrical throttle valve.", "A long gunmetal sleeve fits over this spindle, which is suspended by a steel screw at the top and rotated by bevel gearing at the lower end; near the top of the sleeve lugs are formed, and below these a collar.", "A hollow spherical casing surrounds the sleeve and is free to slide vertically; this casing has formed within it supports for the axes of four double-armed pendulums, the longer vertical arms of which project through the casing and carry balls at their lower ends, while the shorter horizontal arms turn towards the spindle and are connected with the sleeve lugs by short links.", "A helical spring is placed between the sleeve collar and the bottom of the casing.", "A rod is connected at one end with the lower part of the casing and at its lower end to a crank fixed on the valve spindle.", "When the engine shaft rotates above the normal speed, the balls fly outward and they, together with the casing, move upward compressing the spring; this movement acts upon the valve and so reduces the supply of steam."], "other": ["This form of governor can be made as sensitive as desired, and, while being compact, has a considerable motion between its extreme positions; the whole of its working parts, except the sleeve, are utilised in producing the controlling force.", "Inv. 1888-187."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["governor"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1911"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["cylindrical casing keyed to the shaft, having at its lower end projecting arms which support the pivots of the two bellcrank levers", "vertical arms of the bellcranks carry the governor balls", "horizontal arms carry rollers bearing upon the upper flange of a sliding sleeve which surrounds the shaft and is pressed downward by a helical spring contained in the casing", "lower end of the sliding sleeve carries a collar with which the expansion gear is connected", "made as frictionless as possible by the use of ball bearings for the bellcrank pivots, and ball thrust bearings at top and bottom of the sleeve", "cork buffers are provided for the balls to rest upon when at their minimum radius", "When working, the balls move nearly horizontally so that gravity has little effect; the vertical compression of the spring is equal to the radial motion of the balls, which makes the governor very sensitive, so that it will move from its full load position to no load with little change of speed", "sensitiveness is usually 2.5 per cent. from full load to no load for ordinary governing, and 1.25 per cent. for electric lighting"], "other": ["mean speed of 280 rev. per min.", "power of 100 ft. lb.", "sleeve rise of 3 in.", "suitable for the link expansion gear of an engine having a cylinder about 14 in. diam.", "made with an external spring by means of which the speed can be varied while running"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ENGINE GOVERNOR"], "makers": ["Messrs. Napier Bros.", "J. D. and R. D. Napier"], "organisations/institutions": ["Froude"], "dates": ["1888", "1880"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["known as the \u201ccat\u201d governor", "works on the principle of Froude\u2019s dynamometer", "A wheel, shaped like a saucer, with internal curved paddles or vanes, revolves rapidly in a tank of water.", "A similar wheel, mounted on another spindle, faces the first.", "The vanes of the revolving wheel dash the water with force, giving the latter a tendency to rotate, and close the throttle valve; this tendency is resisted by an adjustable spring lever, weighted according to the speed required.", "A duplicate pair of wheels is placed beside the apparatus to show the construction."], "other": ["Inv. 1888-235", "19,374"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Governor"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1888"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A centrifugal governor used for regulating the speed of an engine."], "other": ["object_id: 1955-182"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ALLEN\u2019S GOVERNOR"], "makers": ["Messrs. Whitley Partners"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1892"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["By this governor the supply of steam is regulated by the frictional resistance of a paddle immersed in fluid, and driven by the engine.", "It consists of a standard carrying a shaft, which is driven by a pulley and has a six-armed paddle-wheel keyed to it.", "The wheel is enclosed in a casing attached to a shaft on the same centre line as the driven shaft.", "The interior of the casing is provided with ribs, which just clear the paddles, and is partly filled with oil, so that the rotation of the paddles the fluid exerts a considerable force, tending to rotate the casing by a kind of fluid coupling.", "The motion of the casing is, however, resisted by an adjustable weight hung by a chain from a suitable cam on its shaft, so that the action of the weight increases as the casing is carried round."], "other": ["On the shaft of the casing is a pinion gearing into a segment on the lever of the throttle valve, which is of the equilibrium piston type and contained in the base of the governor.", "A sectional drawing is also shown.", "19,375"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Messrs. Joseph Evans and Sons"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1891"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Three balls are employed, each fixed in the middle of a separate plate spring. These springs are attached to a collar formed on the driving spindle. The upper ends of the springs are secured to a cap at the top of the column, the cap being free to revolve and to rise and fall, so that as the balls diverge under the centrifugal force the top cap is drawn down, carrying with it a central shaft which is connected with a throttle valve contained in the lower casing. A helical spring is arranged to act upon an arm connected with the central spindle, and by means of a worm and worm wheel can be adjusted so as to alter the speed while running.", "The example shown is for a steam pipe 1 in. diam.", "should make 300 rev. per min."], "other": ["Plate VI., No. I.", "Inv. 1891-103, 19,254"]}

Woodhouse & Rawson"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1887", "1884"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This piece of mechanism for controlling electrically the speed of engines or other motors was patented in 1884 by Messrs. A. E. Porte and E. Manville.", "On a horizontal spindle are two ratchet wheels of equal diameter, but with their teeth cut oppositely.", "These wheels are secured to a bevel wheel on the same axis, gearing with a bevel wheel on a vertical shaft, which is connected with the steam throttle valve, a set of resistances, or other means for controlling the energy supplied to the motor.", "On the horizontal spindle is also a rocking frame carrying two opposite pawls which by springs are lifted clear of the ratchet wheels, but the frame is provided with two electro-magnets, each powerful enough when excited to pull the pawl above it into gear.", "The rocking frame is connected by an arm with some reciprocating part of the motor, so that when a pawl engages, the power brought upon the controlling gear may be very great if required.", "The actual regulation is determined by the apparatus that sends the current through one or other of the two coils as necessary, the appliance shown being a means for enforcing these corrections."], "other": ["Inv. 1887-82"]}

Robinson, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1904", "1894\u20139"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["centrifugal governor directly secured to the engine shaft", "speed of the engine is regulated by its varying the point of cut-off of the steam", "altering the position of the eccentric on the shaft in such a way that the angular advance and travel of the valve are varied while the lead remains constant", "mechanism is enclosed in a hollow flywheel or pulley fixed to the engine shaft", "eccentric sheave is carried on one side of a frame composed of a pair of guide plates, placed one on each side of the wheel and connected by four shouldered studs passing through slotted holes in the wheel faces", "studs are joined in pairs by two bridge pieces, which are each tied by two steel strips to opposite lugs on the inside of the wheel rim", "eccentric frame and strips form a \u201cWatt\u201d parallel motion, constraining the eccentric to move approximately in a straight line at right angles to the crank, so as to maintain a practically constant lead", "frame is held in position by a pair of laminated steel springs, curved outward round the boss and passing between the parallel motion strips", "springs are controlled by four swinging levers pivoted at the fulcrums and coupled together in pairs by links and compensating levers; these act through links and rolling contact pieces, which bear upon the inside of the curved part of the springs, so that when the levers fly outward the springs are pulled apart and the eccentric frame is moved towards the centre", "speed of the engine is adjusted by moving the fixed ends of the laminated springs, which can be effected while the engine is in motion by means of a disc sliding along the shaft; this disc carries a projecting rack, which engages with a pinion attached to a right and left handed screw, passing through the ends of short levers upon which the springs are mounted"], "other": ["Inv. 1904-9."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["J. Wood, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["consists of a vertical cylinder that acts as an ordinary jet condenser. Below the condenser is a closed vessel into which the condensed water flows through a foot valve, and from which it is discharged by a delivery valve. Steam is admitted to this closed chamber by a valve driven by tappets on a rotating shaft above, so as to give six short admissions of steam per minute. At the same time that the steam valve is opened a similar delivery valve is opened, the air and condensed water being thus blown out by the steam. The arrangement is equivalent to using Savery\u2019s engine or a pulsometer in the place of the ordinary air pump.", "This form of condenser was patented in 1869\u201373 by Mr. J. W. McCarter, the object being to dispense with the usual air pump.", "A number of lithographs show applications of this condenser."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1412 & 1413.", "1876"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SPECIMENS OF CLARKSON\u2019S ATMOSPHERIC CONDENSER"], "makers": ["Mr. T. Clarkson"], "organisations/institutions": ["Clarkson and Capel Steam Car Syndicate", "Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1901", "1895"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["air-cooled condenser", "construction of air-cooled condenser", "patented in 1895 by Mr. T. Clarkson", "extensively adopted for condensing the steam or cooling the water used in motor cars, owing to the large amount of cooling surface it presents to the air in proportion to the weight of the apparatus.", "The fluid to be cooled is passed through a central tube of thin copper, the specimens shown being 0.25 and 0.5 in. bore respectively, and the exterior of the tube has rolled into it a continuous helical depression into which is wound a continuous helical spring, whose coils slightly interlock and are held into the air bed by an internal wire wound with it. The whole tube, with its added radiating surface, is then dipped in molten tin, by which complete metallic contact is made between the tube and the wires, while increased rigidity is conferred by the connection which the tin establishes between the successive coils at their points of contact. The small diameter of the radiating wire gives great surface in proportion to its weight, while the high conductivity of the copper, together with the metallic connection, ensures that the heat is conveyed to the wire loops as fast as the large amount of freely exposed surface disperses it to the passing air."], "other": ["Inv. 1901-19"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["EJECTOR CONDENSER"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1893", "1882"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This apparatus, patented in 1882 by Mr. E. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["AERO-CONDENSER"], "makers": ["Mons. F. Fouch\u00e9"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1907", "1880\u20131905"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a condensing apparatus of the form patented by Mons. F. Fouch\u00e9 in 1880\u20131905, in which steam is condensed by passing it through passages of special form around which an opposite current of air is induced by a fan. It may also be used to heat air by means of exhaust or live steam for drying or ventilating purposes.\nThe apparatus consists of a rectangular sheet iron chamber, at one end of which is fitted a fan driven by an electric motor. Within the chamber are placed vertically a number of hollow plates, each consisting of two thin metal sheets fastened together at the edges, a short distance apart, thus forming narrow rectangular passages which expose a large surface to the air current. These plates are connected together, with the steam inlet at one end and with the outlet at the other end, the steam flowing in the opposite direction to the air. At the connection each plate has a circular orifice surrounded by a concentric projection on one sheet and a corresponding depression on the other, and between the two sheets is inserted a perforated ring which supports the joints while allowing the steam to pass through the plates. Between each pair of plates suitably shaped distance rings are placed, and closing washers over the holes in the outside members of the group; the plates and rings are then drawn tightly together by bolts passing through the connecting holes, jointing material being introduced if necessary. The sheets forming the hollow plates are stayed at intervals by being stamped inward to meet, and riveted together."], "other": ["Lent by Mons. F. Fouch\u00e9", "Inv. 1907-2", "The small specimen shown will deliver 350 cub. ft. of air per min., with the fan running at 2,000 rev. per min.; it will condense 35 lb. of steam per hour and raise the temperature of the air from 60 deg. F. to 124 deg. F. when working without a vacuum, or 22 lb. of steam and an air temperature of 100 deg. F. when working with a vacuum."]}

Dixon & Son, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1920", "1862"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["intended for such situations, e.g., locomotives, where glass sight feeds are inapplicable", "of the form patented in 1862 by Mr. J. Roscoe", "The vessel, filled with oil, is in communication with the cylinder, &c., by a horizontal steam pipe which can be closed by a screw-in valve opposite to it.", "Steam entering the vessel is condensed by contact with the lubricant, and displaces a drop of oil which passes out by the same pipe as that by which the steam entered. Mollerin"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1907", "1881"], "places": ["France", "the Continent", "this country"], "descriptions": ["positively driven lubricator", "employed extensively on the Continent", "a modified form is manufactured in this country", "consists of a lower vessel to contain oil, fitted with a hollow plunger or piston, which is actuated by an arrangement of ratchet, worm and screw gearing", "The upper end of the piston forms a nut for a square-threaded screw which has a worm driven by a ratchet wheel, the latter obtaining its motion by its attachment to a reciprocating part of the engine", "at every stroke of the engine a slight turn is imparted to the square-threaded screw, and this, being fixed in position, causes the nut, i.e., the piston, to descend and force out oil into the distributing pipe, which is attached to the upper part of the oil cylinder", "The rate of oil feed can be adjusted to suit the requirements by moving a sliding block on the ratchet arm", "When a wing nut above the plunger screw is tightened, the worm wheel and the screw rotate as one, but when this nut is loose, the worm wheel and the plunger can be raised or lowered by turning the handle at the top of the lubricator", "To fill the lubricator, the wing nut is slackened and the plunger is drawn to the top of its stroke", "Oil can then be poured into the lower vessel through the cup at the side", "The rotation of the plunger is prevented by a piece of bent wire, U-shaped at its upper end, which is guided by a vertical fixed wire rod", "The screw is only just long enough to allow the plunger to reach its lowest position and empty the vessel of oil; any further rotation then winds the screw out of the plunger"], "other": ["Inv. 1907-10", "worm and screw gearing", "ratchet wheel", "reciprocating part of the engine", "square-threaded screw", "sliding block on the ratchet arm", "wing nut", "bent wire", "vertical fixed wire rod"]}

C. Fulle in 1919", "intended to replace strainers which are dependent for their action on gauze or perforated metal", "The oil or other fluid is passed through a series of fine slots in the wall of a cylindrical cartridge formed by a pile of circular metal discs mounted on a central spindle and interleaved by thin washers, the thickness of which is a measure of the fineness of the straining required", "The dirt suspended in the liquid is intercepted by the edges of the discs, which in course of time become coated", "To clear off the dirt the handle at the end of the strainer is given a quarter turn, which revolves the discs against a series of stationary cleaning blades which are slightly thinner than the distance between the slots. The cleaning edge of the blades is set obliquely to the periphery of the cartridge face. The blades therefore have a wedging action on the dirt, carrying it from the inside to the outside of the slot, and clear of the cartridge face. The dirt settles to the bottom of the sump provided which may be cleaned out by removing the screwed plug. The base, coupling bolts and tubular body can be removed, fully exposing the cartridge if required for inspection purposes."], "other": ["1919", "Inv. 1924-350"]}

Bevan in 1908", "The nut has a longitudinal slot cut inside it, deeper at one edge than the other", "A grooved roller lies in this slot and is pressed towards the narrow end by a flat spring", "should the nut tend to unscrew, the roller jams itself between the bolt thread and the back of the slot, preventing further relative motion", "A hardened plate is inserted in the slot behind the roller, and the nut is recessed at the top and bottom for the reception of lipped washers that hold the roller and springs in place; the ends of the rollers are turned smaller for this purpose", "In order to release the nut, a pin or wire nail is inserted through a hole in the top washer", "One of the specimens shown, which are for bolts of 1 in. diam., has two rollers fitted so that it cannot move in either direction until a releasing pin is placed between the rollers to hold them out of engagement with the bolt"], "other": ["Inv. 1909-124 to 126"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["RECIPROCATING COUNTER"], "makers": ["Sch\u00e4ffer & Budenberg"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1914"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a six-figure counter, actuated by a reciprocating lever, for registering the number of revolutions of an engine. The number dials are placed side by side on parallel spindles, and are numbered on their faces. Beneath each dial, and fixed to its spindle, are two toothed wheels and a finger; one of the wheels has 10 saw-shaped teeth, and the other is similar, but has one tooth cut away. The driving lever is pivoted on the base of the counter, and its shorter arm engages with the 10-tooth wheel on the first spindle and moves it one-tenth of a revolution on each forward stroke. On the completion of one revolution of the units dial, the finger on its spindle engages with the 10-tooth wheel on the second spindle and rotates it one-tenth of a revolution, and so on throughout the series. The dials are held stationary between movements by spring pawls engaging with the 10-toothed wheels. The dials may be set to zero by a sliding bar carrying six hook-shaped springs that engage with the nine-toothed wheels and pull them round until the missing tooth prevents further movement."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-286"]}

Barlow"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1876", "1875"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["designed to show on a dial the speed of a revolving shaft, in rev. per min.", "differs from most appliances of the class in that it is a combination of a clock and a counter, and gives a result that has been averaged over a definite interval.", "The speed is shown by a pointer, carried loosely on a sleeve, which forms part of a clutch and is driven from a clock train at the rate of one turn per min.", "The clutch is released momentarily by ratchet gearing, driven from the shaft whose speed is to be observed, and so arranged that the clockwork steadily moves the pointer sleeve while the shaft makes 1200 rev. and then releases it, so that the distance thus travelled by the pointer is greater the lower the speed of the shaft.", "The pointer and sleeves are, by spiral springs, continually tending to fly back to the starting position when released, and the pointer is also fitted with a brake which retains it over its last reading till it is momentarily released, to permit of its moving into the fresh position should the speed have altered during the last interval.", "In another and more obvious form of the instrument, the shaft drives the clutch and pointer, while the clockwork releases the clutch at intervals of one minute, the pointer being, however, retained at its last reading as above until the end of the fresh minute."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1442 to 1443"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Barlows motometer", "Barlow's patent 'motometer' speed indicator"], "makers": ["Barlow"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1875-1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Motive Power watercolour; drawing; watercolour; drawing"], "other": ["No.2092"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TACHOMETER"], "makers": ["Messrs. Buss, Sombart & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1909", "1877", "1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["instrument for indicating the speed of a rotating shaft", "mechanism consists of a centrifugal governor, connected, by levers and gearing, to a pointer which moves over a graduated dial", "governor is of the special cosine form", "placed with its axis horizontal", "sliding sleeve is controlled by a weighted lever, outside the casing, which gives a load increasing with the displacement", "governor consists of two semi-cylindrical weights, pivoted by their axes at points some distance from the axis of the shaft", "Arms on these weights are directly connected with swivelling bolts attached to the casing, and bears upon a guide plate, which is in contact with rollers mounted on the controlling lever", "pressure on the sleeve is dependent only upon the angular velocity of the shaft, and not upon the position of the parts, so that the pointer will always indicate correctly in spite of any wear that may take place", "very stable, a large range of speed being covered between its extreme positions", "driving shaft is carried in a long bearing, upon the outside of which the driving pulley runs, so that no belt pressure is transmitted to the axis of the shaft", "dial is mounted on the top of the casing", "axis of the controlling lever carries another lever which is connected, by a vertical rod, with a shorter lever placed upon the axis of a toothed sector behind the dial, and the sector gears with a pinion on the axis of the pointer", "divisions on the dial are made more uniform"], "other": ["Inv. 1909-93"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This instrument indicates directly on a dial, in rev. per min., the speed at which an engine shaft, etc., to which it is connected by a belt drive, is running.", "The acting mechanism is of the Buss-Sombart governor type, patented in 1877 (see No. 312), and consists of a spring-loaded pendulum having four cylindrical weights mounted on two rectangular frames, and working on pivots, formed on the revolving spindle.", "The position assumed by the governor weights under centrifugal action is transmitted to the index pointer by means of two connecting links attached to a movable sleeve inside the tachometer spindle.", "To damp out oscillations of the pointer when subjected to sudden speed fluctuations, the pointer spindle is fitted with a large gear wheel engaging with a shaft carrying a \"fly\" consisting of a four-armed air vane.", "The pulley spindle is geared to the tacho-meter spindle in the ratio of 2 : 1, thus obviating inconvenient pulley sizes.", "The working parts are lubricated by two wick-feed oil-cups."], "other": ["Inv. 1921-730", "1921"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["RECORDING GYROMETER AND COUNTER"], "makers": ["Sir W. H. Bailey & Co., Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1919", "1919-399"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["combined instrument which indicates the speed of a rotating shaft, counts the number of revolutions, and also makes a permanent record of these quantities on a daily chart", "mechanism is contained within a substantial cast-iron casing", "driving spindle projects through the side of the casing", "gyrometer, or speed indicator, placed in the lower part of the casing", "consists of a centrifugal governor of special form which is very sensitive to changes of speed and at the same time steady", "running parts are of hardened steel", "shafts run in ball bearings", "drive is taken from the rotating shaft to the driving spindle by means of a special tape band", "range of speed is from 200 to 800 rev. per min.", "counter is mounted above the gyrometer", "index moving over a large dial counts from 0 to 1,000 rev.", "four small dials carry the readings up to ten millions", "On top of the casing a projecting vertical spindle carries a drum which is rotated once in 24 hours by clockwork", "chart is wrapped round the drum and its upper part is ruled with horizontal lines corresponding to the speeds on the gyrometer dial, and with vertical lines showing hours and quarter hours", "pen, moving vertically in unison with the gyrometer needle, draws a line on the chart showing the variation of speed with time", "On the lower part of the chart is a ruled space, across which a second vertically moving pen is traversed up and down once for every 10,000 rev. recorded by the counter, thus giving a diagram showing the relation between revolutions and time", "glass-fronted cover encloses the recording mechanism"], "other": ["Lent by", "Inv. 1919-399"]}
