Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["RICHARDS'S STEAM ENGINE INDICATOR"], "makers": ["Prof. C. B. Richards", "Mr. Darke"], "organisations/institutions": ["Messrs. Elliott Bros."], "dates": ["1888"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This well-known form of indicator was introduced by Prof. C. B. Richards in 1862, and, except for high-speed engines, is still in use.", "The great improvement it contained was the employment of a multiplying arrangement by which the stroke of the indicator piston is reduced, and the great distortion of the diagram, through the inertia of the moving parts of the instrument, is generally avoided.", "The capacity and convenience of the apparatus was also improved in most of the instruments since introduced have followed the methods that Richards invented.", "The instrument consists of a small cylinder containing a piston held by a spiral spring. A drum is also provided to carry the paper on which the diagram is to be drawn, as in McNaught's instrument, but the paper arm is some little distance from the cylinder. Round the cylinder is fitted a collar with two projecting arms which support the two fixed points of a Watt parallel motion. The parallel point of this motion carries the pencil, and the piston is connected with one of the bridle rods at the point that has only one-fourth of the motion of the piston. Owing to this arrangement, the pencil can be swung round to be in contact with the paper just when desired while the instrument is in action, a feature also of the greatest practical importance."], "other": ["Inv. 1888-254", "19,632"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Richards' Steam Indicator"], "makers": ["Richards, Charles"], "organisations/institutions": ["Elliott Brothers"], "dates": ["1862", "1862-1888"], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["with accessories, in wooden box. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["\u201cSIMPLEX\u201d INDICATOR"], "makers": ["Messrs. Elliott Bros."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1905", "1894"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["steam-engine indicator, which is a modified form of one patented by Mr. M. J. Wayne in 1894, the ordinary helical spring is replaced by a bow spring situated outside the cylinder away from the action of the steam. This can be easily removed and replaced, as its ends simply fit into grooves provided in the top of the extended piston rod and a fixed piece above, and are retained in position by a small spring pin in one of the grooves engaging with a notch. The piston is 0.5 sq. in. area, and its travel is magnified four times by the pencil mechanism which consists of a pantograph combination of levers. A detent stop motion is fitted to the paper drum, and the tension of the drum spring can be adjusted by means of a milled head attached to its lower end."], "other": ["Inv. 1905-28", "30,066"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["CROSBY \u201cNEW\u201d INDICATOR WITH CONTINUOUS DRUM"], "makers": ["Crosby Steam Gage and Valve Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1879 and 1907", "1913"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["generally similar to No. 327, but it has an external spring and is fitted with a special drum for automatically taking a series of diagrams on a continuous strip of paper.", "This type of drum is very useful where the load varies constantly, as in winding or rolling mill engines, and also when it is desired to take separate diagrams at intervals too short to allow of the card being changed in the ordinary way.", "The indicator piston has a spherical edge and an area of 1 sq. in.; the pencil connection is made by a small rod fitted inside the hollow piston rod and terminating at its lower end in a ball joint.", "The piston rod is extended upwards and one end of the spring is clamped to the end of it; the lower end of the spring is fitted to a screwed nose fixed to a bridge piece mounted above the cylinder, and it may be screwed up or down to adjust the position of the pencil. This arrangement removes the springs from the effects of the high temperature and facilitates changing them.", "The continuous drum is mounted on the indicator arm in place of the ordinary one, and has an external drum 2 in. diam. rotated by a cord and returned by a central helical spring.", "This drum has a vertical slot in it, within which the roll of paper is mounted on a removable spindle. The paper passes from this roll round outside the drum, and through the slot on to a smaller internal drum, to which its end is clipped; the edges of the slot are provided with anti-friction rollers.", "The paper is wound on to the central drum by means of two ratchet clutches, one connecting the outer drum with the inner drum and the other connecting the inner drum with the fixed central spindle. The inner clutch holds the central drum stationary for a certain space at the end of each out-stroke of the main drum, so that the latter overruns the inner drum and so winds the paper on to it; this clutch can be so adjusted that the advance of the paper at each revolution of the drum can be regulated to give the desired number of diagrams per foot of paper. The motion of the paper is stopped by throwing out of gear the pawl of the outer ratchet clutch.", "A fixed pencil is mounted on the drum to continue the atmospheric line on the moving paper. The cord guide of the drum can be set in any position to suit the lead from the engine. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["indicator", "indicator cord"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["An arm extending from the indicator connection supports a horizontal spindle running in ball bearings and carrying a pulley, round which the indicator cord is wrapped and secured.", "A vertical spindle is fixed below the arm and carries a light pulley, round which is wrapped another cord, the end of which is connected with the engine crosshead.", "The two pulleys are connected by bevel gearing with a ratio of 3 : 1, and the horizontal spindle is rotated against the action of an adjustable helical spring contained in a projecting casing.", "The upper or stroke pulley consists of a number of movable concentric rings by means of which its diameter may be varied to suit different engine strokes from 14 in. to 72 in.; this pulley is connected with the spindle through a clutch which allows the pulley to be held stationary by means of a spring detent, so that the motion of the indicator may be stopped when desired.", "The lower drum is fitted with a moving guide for properly coiling the cord."], "other": ["Inv. 1912-89"]}

John Musgrave & Sons, Ltd."], "dates": ["1890"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Starting from a point in the toe of the diagram, and with the measuring wheel at zero, the tracing point is led round the diagram, and with the completing the circuit, the fresh reading on the wheel is the area of the diagram in square inches. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1921"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["consists in its simplest form of a flap or disc within a conical-shaped casting screwed to the pipe to be controlled", "spindle has fixed upon it an external weight (or a spring), which is balanced by the normal pressure of the liquid within the pipe", "On any failure of the pressure the valve turns automatically and moves a lever, which brings into operation electrical or mechanical alarm gear", "spindle of the valve is provided with anti-friction glands of special design to allow of rotation without leakage", "It also resets itself when normal running is attained", "it is not the static pressure of the water, but its momentum, which keeps the valve open", "two types of these valves, one for an open-ended pipe, which is the most usual arrangement, and the other for a closed circulation system under pressure, as represented by the example here shown", "alarm gear is of several kinds; in this case it is a whistle, which is the device suitable for steam-driven pumps or for air-compressors", "connection to the whistle is from the pump steam chest or from the compressor intercooler and thus, while automatic, only functions when the plant is actually working", "general arrangement for an air-compressor is shown by a diagram", "In other cases such as a gas engine having forced circulation of cooling water, the Monitor valve may close an electrical circuit so as to ring a bell, or to actuate a plunger, e.g., to cut the magneto out of circuit", "Other applications are obvious"], "other": ["size C", "for a pipe 2 in. diam.", "Inv. 1921-716"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Device that automatically closes a valve when flow pressure fails, triggering an alarm.", "The alarm is activated by a whistle, suitable for steam-driven pumps or air compressors.", "Designed to respond to momentum rather than static pressure."], "other": ["SMG-Object-20036146"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF HAYSTACK BOILER", "flange boiler", "balloon boiler"], "makers": ["Coalbrookdale Co.", "Thomas Stephens", "Moses Hadley"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1907", "18th century", "late in the 19th century", "about the middle of that century", "about 1760", "1748", "about 1790", "1725", "1776"], "places": ["Staffordshire district"], "descriptions": ["This type of boiler, which together with its setting was only an adaptation of existing practice with brewers\u2019 pans and spirit stills, was used throughout the 18th century for supplying steam to atmospheric engines", "under the name of the \u201cballoon\u201d boiler it survived in the Staffordshire district till late in the 19th century.", "The period represented by the model is about the middle of that century.", "At first it was the practice to place the boiler vertically under the engine cylinder, but about 1760, as the power of engines was increasing, the demand for more steam was met by an increase in the number of the boilers, placed in contiguous settings, rather than in their size.", "The boiler was under-fired and set in masonry or brickwork, so that the hot gases made a complete circuit of the sides on their way to the chimney in a way known as a \u201cwheel draught.\u201d", "As the pressure used was practically only that of the atmosphere, the question of construction was subsidiary to that of heating surface", "the flange boiler, which was the type used with the earliest Newcomen engines, had the side flue formed by a horizontal flange uniting vertical sides to a base plate.", "Later a slight improvement was made by adopting conical or concave sides, hence the name \u201chaystack.\u201d", "The bottom was at one time recessed so as to form a spiral flue, as patented in 1748 by Thomas Stephens and Moses Hadley, but generally it was flat or concave.", "Internal stays were but rarely used, and instances of boilers up to 15 ft. diam. without them are recorded.", "The numerous explosions that had been traced to these defects in shape and construction and the low ratio of heating surface to cubic contents possible, led to the disuse of this type of boiler.", "The material of which the boiler was made was at first copper, often with lead for the top; the corners appear to have been made by flanging the plates.", "On account of their durability and less cost, wrought-iron plates produced by hammering seem to have been substituted as early as 1725.", "Cast iron was also used; even in 1776 Smeaton preferred this material for his boilers.", "It was not till about 1790 that plates and other sections produced by rolling became generally available.", "The feed water was introduced through a valve controlled by hand into a cistern on a vertical stand-pipe by which a column of water of sufficient height to balance the pressure within was obtained.", "The water level was indicated by the position of a lever connected with a float inside.", "The blow-off pipe was usually stopped simply by a wooden plug."], "other": ["Made in the Museum", "(Scale 1:12.)", "Inv. 1907-14.", "S.M. 10.", "11 ft. high", "12 ft. diam. at the dome", "10 ft. diam. at the bottom", "grate area is 25 sq. ft.", "heating surface 235 sq. ft.", "water space about 550 cub. ft.", "steam space 300 cub. ft.", "pressure would not exceed 3 lb. per sq. in."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["boiler"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1780-90", "about 1850"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["remained in general use till about 1850, when the gradual increase that had taken place in boiler pressures led to its abandonment through the inherent weakness of its shape", "usually had a semi-cylindrical top with concave bottom and sides", "set over the furnace, from which the gases, after passing along the bottom of the boiler, returned along one side flue, and then passed back again by the other side flue, following the course known as a \"wheel draught.\"", "At a later period a nearly square central flue through the boiler was introduced, and the gases from the furnace, after passing under the bottom, returned through this flue, dividing at the front, so that one-half of the quantity passed along each of the side flues, thus originating what is known as the \"split draught.\"", "feed water was introduced by a vertical stand-pipe, or \"feed-head,\" of sufficient height to prevent water being blown out of it by the steam pressure", "In this pipe was a float connected with a damper in the main flue, so that if the pressure fell, the rate of combustion was automatically increased", "feed water was supplied to the head from a cistern provided with a valve controlled by a float within the boiler", "20 nominal h.p.", "13.8 ft. long, 6.8 ft. high, 5.33 ft. wide at the water line", "heating surface of 200 sq. ft., a grate area of 29 sq. ft.", "ordinarily contained 300 cub. ft. of water, and had a steam space of 115 cub. ft.", "pressure would be 5 lb. per sq. in."], "other": ["Inv. 1901-20, 25.523"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF HORIZONTAL BOILER ON YIELDING SUPPORTS"], "makers": ["Jeremiah Head, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1876", "1870"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 16", "By this method of supporting a long boiler, patented by Mr. Head in 1870, the ends may rise and fall by expansion without altering the position of the points of support, thus reducing the stresses that frequently cause seam-rips.", "The boiler represented is of the long egg-ended type set in an ordinary brick setting, such as is still used in iron works.", "Pieces of T iron are riveted to the boiler and attached by suspension rods to weighted levers, with their fulcra carried on cast-iron bridges, two intermediate bridges, however, carrying suspension rods fixed by nuts.", "The steam connections are fitted with double bends or U pipes."], "other": ["By a hand wheel on the model the boiler may be curved so as to show the action of these supports."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF ELEPHANT BOILER WITH STEP GRATE"], "makers": ["A. Leinweber & Co., of Gleiwitz"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1914", "about 1820", "1803", "about the middle of the 19th century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The form of externally fired steam generator known as the elephant or French boiler consists of a main steam drum with one or more water drums, parallel to or an up-and-down draft, communicating and set in brickwork with a to-and-fro or simple flue-ended boiler (see No. 341), but has greater heating surface for the same volume. The type was developed about 1820 from a somewhat similar construction patented and introduced in 1803 by Arthur Woolf. It was used in this country at one time as a mill boiler, but was superseded by the Lancashire boiler. The highest development has been reached on the Continent, especially in France, hence one of the names by which it is known here. It remains still an accepted type on the Continent, but is now being displaced by the water-tube boiler.", "The step grate for burning fuel of low calorific value was introduced in Germany about the middle of the 19th century. It consists of a succession of flat bars, stepped one in front of the other terminating in a fixed flat grate, the fuel being introduced by a hopper at the top.", "The model shows a boiler installation made by A. Leinweber & Co., of Gleiwitz, for a pressure of 7.20 lb.", "The steam drum is 1.4 m. (4.6 ft.) diam. and 11 m. (36.1 ft.) long, its thickness being 11 mm. (0.43 in.) except over the fire, where it is 15 mm. (0.59 in.) thick.", "The two water drums are 750 mm. (2.46 ft.) diam. by 9.1 m. (29.9 ft.) long, their thickness being 7 mm. (0.27 in.).", "They are supported on cast-iron stools at a slope of 1 in 32 to the blow-off cock.", "The heating surface is 70 sq. m. (752 sq. ft.).", "The grate is formed of flat plates resting in ledges on side and intermediate bearers, leaving air spaces of about 1 in. measured vertically. The angle of the grate is 35 deg.; these proportions are for wood chips and sawdust, which is the fuel used.", "The flat grate is of the usual construction and is cleaned through a door in the side wall.", "The total grate surface is 3.27 sq. m. (35 sq. ft.), i.e., in the ratio of 1 : 21.4 of the heating surface.", "The fire bridge projects over the grate with the object of preventing smoke.", "The gases are directed up and down by vertical baffle walls situated closer together as the chimney flue is approached."], "other": ["Scale 1 : 12", "Inv. 1914-397, S.M. 548."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF CORNISH BOILER AND SETTING. (Scale 1 : 12.)"], "makers": ["Livet\u2019s Boiler and Furnace Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1903", "1878"], "places": ["Cornish"], "descriptions": ["The boiler has a single furnace flue, and is carried in a setting provided with flues which give a \u201cwheel draught\u201d (see No. 339).", "The special arrangements illustrated by the model are, however, the construction of the furnace bars and the setting patented by Mr. F. Livet in 1878.", "The bars are made of wedge section about 12 in. deep, for the purpose of warming the air passing through them; while, to avoid breakage from unequal expansion, each bar is composed of a separate upper and lower portion.", "The boiler is supported on cast-iron cradles built into a continuous mid-feather wall, there being thus only two external flues;", "the gases pass through these flues in succession, and the section of the flues increases as the chimney end is approached.", "The flues are made of exceptionally large dimensions, with the object of retaining the hot gases for a longer time than usual in proximity with the boiler shell;", "their size also reduces the chimney draught required, and facilitates cleaning and inspection.", "Made in the Museum"], "other": ["Inv. 1903-96", "Made in the Museum, 1903"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1903"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A scale model of a Cornish boiler and its setting, built in 1903 by the Museum based on information from Livet's Boiler and Furnace Co. It showcases a single furnace flue boiler with a specific setting and furnace bars patented by F. Livet in 1878. The design aims to improve air warming, prevent bar breakage, and optimize flue gas retention and draught.", "The boiler features a single furnace flue and is supported by cast-iron cradles within a continuous mid-feather wall, creating two external flues.", "The furnace bars are wedge-shaped for air warming and constructed in two parts to avoid breakage due to unequal expansion."], "other": ["OBJ 228546"]}

Richardsons, Westgarth and Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1878\u201397"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The construction of vertical boiler embodies several arrangements patented by Mr. J. Blake", "The shell is cylindrical with a domed top containing the manhole", "the firebox is in the form of an oblique cone, fitting the shell at the bottom and inclining to the back, where it is connected with the base of a cylindrical combustion chamber having a dished top", "These forms avoid the use of stays and therefore facilitate cleaning", "The combustion chamber is completely surrounded by water, and from its front seventy horizontal fire tubes extend radially to the shell which is bossed out, where necessary, to receive normally those tubes which would pierce it obliquely", "The grate is fired through a short oval tube connecting the firebox with the shell, while the smokebox, which is attached to the shell higher up and carries the chimney base, is provided with hinged doors for use when cleaning the tubes", "A separate mid-length section of the boiler shows an alternative arrangement of the combustion chamber and tubes", "The chamber has a domed top and cylindrical back, which is stayed to the shell; the tube plate is flat, as is also the corresponding portion of the shell plating, so that the fire tubes are of uniform length and parallel; there are seventy-seven of these tubes, of which fourteen are provided with nuts so that they serve as stay-tubes"], "other": ["Scale 1: 12", "Inv. 1901-42 & 43"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF GURNEY'S WATER TUBE BOILER."], "makers": ["Sir Goldsworthy Gurney"], "organisations/institutions": ["Navy Office"], "dates": ["1825", "1826", "1827", "1923"], "places": ["Regent\u2019s Basin"], "descriptions": ["For the purposes of his steam carriage Sir Goldsworthy Gurney patented, in 1825, a water-tube boiler which he modified subsequently, as shown, for stationary use.", "This boiler was constructed in 1826 at his manufactory at Regent\u2019s Basin.", "It was tested there in 1827 by Mr. Simon Goodrich on behalf of the Navy Office, but his report was unfavourable.", "The boiler was made of wrought-iron pipes bent to a C shape, the ends being screwed and held by nuts in cast-iron horizontal headers joined by downcomers.", "The headers were joined by bends to a vertical steam \u201c separator \u201d of wrought iron strengthened by hoops.", "This was provided with gauge cocks and a lever safety valve.", "The lower legs of the pipes formed the grate and brick baffles were inserted to make the course of the gases circuitous.", "Lightness, ease of repair and rapidity in getting up steam were claimed as the advantages but difficulties with materials were met with, e.g., pipes at that time were lapwelded and in lengths of not more than 6 ft.", "Probably the circulation was defective ; anyhow the boiler did not survive.", "The heating surface of this boiler was about 60 sq. ft., and the grate area 5\u00b76 sq. ft. ; the content of water was 160 lb.", "The time required to get up steam from the coal was 14 min.", "The evaporation was 6\u00b77 lb. water per lb. of good Newcastle coal at 60 lb. pressure."], "other": ["Scale 1: 6.", "Received 1923.", "Inv. 1923-517.", "Gurney", "Goodrich"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DRAWING OF SECTIONAL STEAM BOILER"], "makers": ["J. Harrison, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1862", "1859", "1859"], "places": ["Philadelphia"], "descriptions": ["Scale I: 15; details I: 2", "It consists of a large number of communicating globular iron chambers, cast in sets of four ; the ends of each set are machined so that tight joints can be made when several sets are held together by internal tie-rods.", "In this way the cells are connected into slabs, while by suitable castings and tie-rods a number of these slabs are similarly united to form a complete boiler of the requisite heating surface.", "The slabs are arranged with a slope of 25 deg. in a brickwork chamber, the furnace being at the lower end and the steam pipe at the top, while suitable bridges distribute the gases between the nests of cells.", "About one-third of the cell capacity is used as steam space, and in it a certain degree of drying or superheating is effected.", "Exceptional portability and adaptability were claimed for the arrangement, as well as great safety, owing to the smallness of the individual elements of which the generator is built up.", "The boiler has since been somewhat modified, and as now constructed is given a slope of 40 deg. with the horizontal.", "On trial it was found that one of these generators, when tested to 875 lb. steam pressure, leaked considerably at the joints, but that it became tight again upon the pressure dropping to 450 lb.", "In some forms of sectional tubulous boilers the use of internal tie-rods has given trouble owing to the expansion of the external tube being greater than that of the rod.", "It consists of a large number of communicating globular iron chambers, cast in sets of four"], "other": ["Inv. 1862-115"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a vertical boiler patented by Mr. J. Richardson in 1873, in which considerable tube surface is introduced. The shell of the firebox is much larger than the grate, and from the space between them, nearly vertical tubes pass upward to the water space, and from the tubes connect with the water space at each end, so that a good circulation of water is secured. From the crown of the firebox the hot gases pass through nearly vertical tubes to the top of the boiler, where by a chimney with a large conical base the waste gases are collected and carried off. In this boiler, therefore, the two sets of tubes act in the reverse manner."], "other": ["Inv. 1874-18", "20,509"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODELS OF STIRLING BOILER", "complete boiler", "boiler in section"], "makers": ["Mr. A. Stirling"], "organisations/institutions": ["Stirling Boiler Co., Ltd."], "dates": ["1903", "1889"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1:12", "This type of water-tube boiler was patented in 1889 by Mr. A. Stirling; a complete boiler and one in section are shown.", "The boiler consists of a number of groups of steeply-inclined tubes, expanded at their upper ends into three cylindrical steam and water chambers, and at their lower ends into two cylindrical mud drums, in which the water, being comparatively quiet, deposits its sediment.", "The feed water is admitted to the upper chamber farthest removed from the fire, and this chamber contains the automatic float for regulating the water level.", "The tubes leading thence to the mud drum serve as downcomers for the water passing to other sections of the boiler and, in heating the feed water, act somewhat like those of an economiser.", "The sides, roof, and floor of the boiler are of brickwork, but the weight of the boiler is carried, and the walls supported, by a steel framing.", "There is a brick arch above the furnace, which assists in directing the flames towards the tubes, and between the groups of tubes are baffles, formed of fireclay slabs, arranged so as to cause the hot gases to traverse the whole of the tube surface before reaching the chimney through the damper door at the back.", "Through the side wall there are protected openings which give access for the scraping tools used in cleaning the exterior of the tubes.", "The steam generated is withdrawn from a steam dome fixed upon the central chamber, into which the steam from the wing chambers is led by curved horizontal pipes, an arrangement which, it is stated, conduces to dryness in the steam."], "other": ["middle size constructed", "56 sq. ft. of grate area", "2,900 sq. ft. of heating surface", "12,000 lb. of steam per hour", "160 lb.", "600 h.p.", "suitable engine", "print of a boiler in longitudinal section", "Inv. 1903-46 & 47", "29,905", "Inv. 1903-112"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Horsfall Destructor Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1907"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["model of forced draught furnace", "shows a furnace, suitable for burning fuel of low calorific value by means of forced draught, provided also with an arrangement for preventing smoke; it is shown fitted to a Cornish boiler, but can be applied to any type.", "The grate is made up, according to the nature of the fuel, either of closely spaced bars or of plate of channel section perforated with a large number of conical holes or slots. Each plate or set of bars forms the cover of a trough into which air is forced by a steam jet of adjustable rectangular cross-section.", "The steam pipe leading to the jets has a pressure gauge, and a stop valve to throttle the steam to the most economical pressure.", "The small quantity of ash falling through the holes into the trough is removed by a rake of special form. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1879"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The feature of the firebox, introduced by Messrs. Garrett in 1876, is the means by which the roof is prevented from collapsing under internal pressure. The usual flat roof and girder stays are dispensed with. Smith, Druce & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum"], "dates": ["1908", "1819\u201320", "1819\u201320"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1:16", "illustrates the revolving grate mechanical stoker patented by William Brunton in 1819\u201320", "first successful one of its kind and was somewhat widely adopted", "apparatus is applied to a brewing copper", "set with a wheel draught (see No. 339)", "grate is circular and surrounded by a fire-bridge of brick supported in a frame driven at about 1 rev. per min. by gearing from the same vertical shaft which operates the stoker", "To prevent access of air except through the fuel, a flange on the under side of the grate frame runs in an annular trough filled with sand.", "The ashes as they drop are received on an apron attached to this shaft and are swept off by a fixed scraper.", "There is a door of the usual construction for lighting the fire and clinkering.", "The stoker is of the shovel type.", "Coal from a hopper is admitted in adjustable amount by a slide actuated by a cam on the vertical shaft and returned by a weight.", "The coal falls on to a shovel which travels on rails; when nearing the grate it tilts on its axis and drops the coal on the grate in a radial position.", "The to-and-to motion of the shovel is derived from a cord attached to a lever actuated by a cam and returned by a weight.", "The periods of rest are timed by the cams.", "The tilting motion is derived from a guide rail and switch below.", "The shovel made about 12 strokes per min.; it is boxed in to prevent access of air to the fire."], "other": ["Inv. 1908-54", "S.M. 1294 and 1295"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1843"], "places": ["Old Ford, near Bow", "Croydon Railway"], "descriptions": ["9.5 ft. long by 30 in. wide", "15 ft. long by 27 in. wide", "furnace bars are placed transversely, and are carried by two longitudinal screws between whom threads the end of the bars loosely rest", "screws are continuously rotated by power, and thus move the bars towards the back of the furnace, where they descend and afterwards engage with the threads of two similar screws below, which bring the bars back again to the front of the furnace, where they are automatically elevated to the grate level and again advanced", "upper screws the threads are cut \" drunken \" towards the back of the furnace, so that the bars receive a rocking motion which tends to detach any clinker formed, while the lower screws have an irregularity in their pitch which separates the bars so as to allow any cinders that drop to fall between them"], "other": ["Inv. 1857-14", "S.M. 1408"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Messrs. Richard Moreland & Son"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1841", "1902"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["improved form of the mechanical stoker", "most generally applied to under-fired boilers", "successfully used with those of the through furnace flue class and of the water-tube type", "chief feature of the furnace is that the fire bars are in short lengths and pinned together, so as to form the links of a wide pitch chain which is moved by sprocket wheels at an adjustable rate, by ratchet and reduction gearing from an external source of power", "top surface of this travelling grate is maintained level by a series of transverse carrying rollers, and the sag of the lower return portion is restricted in the same way, while the wear of the links can be taken up by adjusting screws which move the bearings of the inner sprocket wheels", "fuel is contained in a hopper at the front, from which it falls on to the in-going portion of the grate, the depth of fuel thus let in being regulated by an adjustable sliding door", "first portion of the furnace is covered by a low firebrick arch which heats the in-going coal and drives off the most volatile gases, so that they shall be consumed by passing over the full length of the fire", "whole grate and its supports are carried on a truck which can be moved in or out on rails when, as in the case of the brewery copper shown, the fire has to be withdrawn upon the completion of a boil while the charge is being drawn off and a fresh one introduced", "practically smokeless, even when using inferior fuel, and it gives a high evaporative efficiency", "gases pass round the boiler through flues which give a split draught, and then escape to a chimney, which is shown supported on rolled joists and provided with sliding doors for cleaning purposes"], "other": ["WALL DIAGRAMS OF JUCKES\u2019S FURNACE", "Inv. 1902-41"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["stoker"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1877"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["fitted to the front of a Cornish boiler", "furnace flue of which has been cut out to show the arrangement of the grate", "fuel is stored in a large hopper above the stoker", "fed by two inclined rectangular plungers, slowly reciprocated by two eccentrics on a countershaft driven by a ratchet feed from some source of power", "pawl of the ratchet acts on a projecting pin on an adjustable masking wheel, by which the attendant can regulate the supply of fuel to suit the steam demand", "plungers work alternately and slowly push fuel on to a short perforated dead plates, from which it falls on to the furnace", "alternate bars of which are connected with two crossheads reciprocated horizontally by cams on the countershaft", "motion given to the bars is such that, although both sets move backward together, they move forward at different times; in this way the spaces between the bars are freed from clinker, and the mass of fuel is slowly worked towards the further end of the furnace, where the clinker and cinders accumulate and form a bank which acts as a fire-bridge, the excess being removed at intervals by raking it from the ash pit"], "other": ["Inv. 1877-443", "19,251 and 19,260"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1875"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1:12", "This sprinkler stoker, which was originally patented by Mr. Proctor in 1875, and has since been considerably simplified and improved, the feeding is performed by a flap, which jerks the fuel on to the grate in a way resembling hand-firing with a shovel, the further distribution of the charge being accomplished by the use of reciprocating fire bars.", "The model shows the stoker fitted to the front of a Lancashire boiler, and feeding from a single coal hopper above, from which the fuel is distributed by a block, reciprocated horizontally along a pipe, to a small chamber at the front of each furnace.", "In each of these chambers is a flap which is moved away from the furnace by pegs on a revolving crank plate and then rapidly swung forward by the action of a spring, thus throwing and distributing the fuel on to the grate in small quantities.", "The fire bars are arranged in pairs alternately fixed and moving, the latter receiving a slow combined vertical and horizontal movement from a crank pin on a shaft driven by worm gearing.", "The whole of the motions are derived from a countershaft driven from an engine or by other means.", "Beneath each automatic feed hopper is a hinged flap for regulating the admission of air, and for use as a fire-door should hand-firing be resorted to."], "other": ["Inv. 1888-285", "19,252"]}

Newton, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1918", "1853"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a gauge in which the pressure is measured by the deflection of a flat diaphragm, the deflection being magnified, and the pressure indicated by a column of fluid in a glass tube leading from the diaphragm chamber.", "The instrument consists of a cast-iron chamber 3 in. diam., made in two parts, bolted together with a thin steel plate between them.", "Steam or other fluid is admitted to the lower part of the chamber, below the diaphragm, while the upper part communicates with a glass tube 0.2 in. diam. mounted in a brass casing, on the face of which the pressure scale is engraved.", "The fluid contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the other suitable fluid, contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the pressure deflects the diaphragm and rises in the tube, the motion being magnified in the ratio of the diameter of the chamber and tube."], "other": ["Inv. 1918-221", "cast-iron chamber 3 in. diam.", "glass tube 0.2 in. diam.", "The instrument must be calibrated from a standard gauge, when using the same fluid as that for which it is to be used, as allowance has to be made for the expansion of the measuring fluid when using the gauge for steam pressures. The scale covers a range from o to 200 lb. per sq. in., and the space between the scale divisions diminishes as the pressure increases."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["mercury gauge", "thermometric gauge"], "makers": ["Smith Bros. and Co.", "Mr. Sydney Smith"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group", "Tapton colliery", "George Stephenson"], "dates": ["1902", "1847", "1854", "40 years"], "places": ["Nottingham"], "descriptions": ["As boiler pressures increased, the mercury gauge originally used became very inconvenient, owing to the height of the column required; hence locomotive drivers were unprovided with any means of telling the steam pressure; in a few instances a form of thermometric gauge was adopted, but the usual practice was to rely upon the indications derived from the spring-loaded safety valve.", "The gauge consisted of a diaphragm of vulcanised india-rubber held at its circumference between flanges which connected the two halves of a spherical chamber. The lower half of the chamber was in communication with the boiler, and the upper half supported a rod, so connecting it with the centre of the diaphragm that it indicated in a greatly magnified manner the amount of bulging which the pressure was occasioning.", "The diaphragm is still of vulcanised rubber, but it is loaded or reinforced by a close volute spring wound with such a camber that at the working pressure it is approximately flat.", "To the centre of the spring is secured a vertically guided rack gearing into a pinion on the index spindle, as shown in the attached sectional drawing.", "in use for 40 years", "of this later type"], "other": ["Inv. 1902-141 & 189", "boiler pressures", "locomotive drivers"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PRESSURE GAUGES", "Bourdon Pressure Gauge"], "makers": ["J. Dewrance and Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1862", "1849", "1862-110"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The form of pressure gauge shown was introduced in 1849 by Mons. E. Bourdon, who discovered the action upon which it relies while attempting to remove, by the application of internal pressure, the flattening caused in a pipe by bending it into a coil. When a fluid pressure was applied the pipe slightly straightened, and by fitting the free end with a pointer, found that reliable readings of the pressure were thus obtainable. This action depends on the fact that the product of the curvatures of a surface in planes at right angles is constant, so that if one radius of curvature is diminished, as by the elliptical section becoming more nearly circular, the other radius increases. The gauge consists of a thin curved tube of elliptical section, with one end fixed in a block to which the admission pipe is attached, while the other end is free; this end is closed and connected by multiplying gear with the index. In one of the forms shown, a link from the end of the tube is connected with a short extension of the index finger, which is pivoted near the edge of the dial. In the other the link is connected with a pivoted lever having a toothed sector that gears with a pinion on the axis of the index, which is mounted centrally so that the scale may extend round the whole circumference of the dial."], "other": ["Mons. E. Bourdon", "index"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["INTERMITTENT PRESSURE RECORDER"], "makers": ["Mr. A. Rigg"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1859", "1907", "1859-60"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Designed and made by Mr. A. Rigg in 1859.", "This instrument was designed and made by Mr. A. Rigg in 1859.", "Its object was to record the pressure, once in every thousand revolutions, of a beam engine driving millstones for grinding white lead.", "The instrument is connected with the engine by the shaft projecting from the front of the box, which drove a ratchet inside, operating three discs acting as cams.", "The cams revolved at different speeds, and when the notches cut in them coincided, a small lever, held in contact with the cams by a spring, fell into the depression and opened a valve, putting the indicator (the McNaught indicator (see No. 321)), into communication with the engine cylinder; the steam pipe for this connection is shown at the back of the box.", "The variations in pressure were thus admitted, then recorded, on an endless paper band, the variations in pressure for one complete revolution of the engine.", "The travel of the paper band round the drum was about 0.25 in. for every thousand revolutions of the engine, and as the engine made 18 rev. per min., the intervals of recording pressure were about 55 min.", "A portion of a record taken with this instrument in 1859-60 is shown.", "The recorder was also used for testing the continuity of a water supply by taking the pressure at every thousand revolutions of a water wheel temporarily arranged to drive it."], "other": ["Inv. 1907-141", "McNaught indicator (see No. 321)"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Contributed by the Seal Lock and Registering Pressure Gauge Co., Ltd.", "The feature of this gauge, patented by Mr. G. A. Everett in 1873, is that, in addition to the ordinary indication of the actual pressure, it is made to indicate the number of times a given pressure has been exceeded in the working of the apparatus to which the gauge is fixed, and also the extent to which such pressure has been exceeded. The latter object is effected by a short index or pointer, which turns about the same axis as the ordinary index, and is pushed forward by it as the pressure rises, and remains as a record of the maximum attained. The number of times that a given pressure has been exceeded is recorded by three small pointers working on one axis, driven by a system of ratchet wheels.", "ordinary indication of the actual pressure", "indicate the number of times a given pressure has been exceeded", "indicate the extent to which such pressure has been exceeded", "short index or pointer, which turns about the same axis as the ordinary index, and is pushed forward by it as the pressure rises, and remains as a record of the maximum attained", "three small pointers working on one axis, driven by a system of ratchet wheels"], "other": ["Inv. 1874-140."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["feed valve"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1914-192"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["float is lifted and the controlling valve is lowered by the toggle levers until it rests on its upper seat", "Steam can then pass from the float chamber to the regulator cylinder so as to force down the piston and close the feed valve", "controlling valve is raised on to its lower seat, steam is cut off from the regulator and its cylinder is exhausted to the atmosphere, so that the spring comes into action and re-opens the feed valve", "steam connection between the controlling valve and the regulator is fitted with a double-seated valve, which in one position permits steam to pass to the regulator, but in the other position shuts off the steam and permanently puts the regulator to atmosphere, so that the latter may be put out of action if desired", "In case of puncture of the float or breakage of the mechanism, the feed valve will remain wide open, so that there will be no risk of shortness of water", "water level can be maintained within 0.125 in. of correct level with ordinary boilers, or within 0.25 in. with water-tube boilers"], "other": ["2 in. diam. feed pipe"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF OIL SEPARATOR"], "makers": ["Messrs. Bakers (Leeds), Ltd.", "Mr. W. J. Baker"], "organisations/institutions": ["Bakers (Leeds), Ltd."], "dates": ["1921", "1902 onwards"], "places": ["Leeds"], "descriptions": ["Scale about 1:4", "The trouble brought about by the presence of grease in boiler feed water is well known, but the loss of efficiency in feed heaters, etc., owing to the deposition of oil carried forward by exhaust steam has not been so widely recognised.", "The mechanical separator shown is for the purpose of removing such oil.", "The separator is most conveniently made, as shown, cylindrical in form, with the inlet and outlet branches arranged to suit its position.", "The exhaust steam carrying oil and water in suspension enters an expansion compartment, where reduction of velocity and temperature takes place, allowing the water and oil to coalesce into drops that impinge on the sides and on the surface of water, filling the lower part of the vessel 3 to 6 in. in depth.", "The steam passes under a deflector or baffle into the second compartment, where it impinges on vertical angles of special section staggered in rows.", "The oil and water so arrested trickle down these collectors by gravity and float off at the grease off-take, which is provided on the shell behind these collectors.", "It is claimed that the apparatus is thus self-cleansing.", "A drain on the bottom cover is provided for periodical blow-off purposes.", "A set of water-gauges is fitted to indicate the water-level.", "The apparatus is applicable also for other purposes, such as the extraction of tar from fuel gas.", "The apparatus is made in a very large number of sizes, from 1.5 in. diam. exhaust (160 lb. of steam per hour) to 40 in. diam. (150,000 lb. per hour)."], "other": ["Inv. 1921-657", "Lent"]}

Joseph Wright & Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1901", "1871\u20136"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this heater, which was patented by Mr. R. Berryman in 1871\u20136, the exhaust steam from the engine is passed through a group of U-tubes, secured into a V-shaped tube plate which serves also as a diaphragm between the steam inlet and outlet; improvements in detail, including the combination with it of an oil separator, have since been added by the makers.", "The upper part of the apparatus is made of boiler plate and surrounds the tubes, but can be lifted off for cleaning them externally; into it the feed-water is introduced, the deposited impurities settling in the V-shaped depression of the tube plate from whence they are washed out at intervals.", "Beneath this shell is the middle belt, into which the steam enters on one side and, after passing through the tubes, is condensed into water which collects in the base.", "The base is divided by a diaphragm, which also supports the tube plate and has openings below through which any remaining steam can pass away; the collected water is discharged by a siphon when it exceeds a certain depth."], "other": ["Scale 1:8", "R. Berryman"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["feed-water heater"], "makers": ["J. Atkinson"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1890", "1877"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this feed-water heater, patented by Mr. J. Atkinson in 1877, the exhaust steam from the engine enters at the steam inlet and passes in a direct unimpeded course through a channel provided for it, which is of a similar sectional area throughout, to the steam outlet, from which the exhaust pipe conducts away the steam not utilised in heating the water.The channel is open at the top to the lower side of the tube plate. Screwed into the tube plate are a number of vertical tubes, open to the exhaust steam at the bottom, but closed at their upper ends, which are left perfectly free to expand or contract without straining. In each of these heating tubes is a small circulating tube leading from near their upper ends to the channel through which the exhaust steam passes, and the mouths are so arranged that the passing steam causes an induced current out of them, and thus out of the upper ends of the heating tubes, removing the air which they contain, or which may be carried in with the exhaust steam, and causing them to be filled with steam. A small portion of the heating tubes projects into the exhaust steam, and assists in diverting the steam into them."], "other": ["Inv. 1890-107"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["feed water heater", "drawing"], "makers": ["Atkinson"], "organisations/institutions": ["British Gas Engine and Engineering Co."], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": [], "other": ["framed in Museum Motive Power drawing"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["direct-acting flywheel donkey pump"], "makers": ["J. Cameron, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1887", "1852"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This type of direct-acting flywheel donkey pump was patented by Mr. Cameron in 1852, and has since been extensively adopted for boiler feeding and similar work. The steam cylinder is arranged vertically over the pump barrel, and the pump rod is attached to an inverted kite-shaped casting which terminates in the pump plunger; within the loop of this casting is arranged a connecting rod, attached to it and to the overhanging crank of a flywheel shaft, so that direct action is secured while the control of a crank and flywheel is retained. The slide valve is worked by an eccentric on the crankshaft, and the other end of this shaft is provided with another crank working a similar single-acting pump; the cranks are set opposite, so that the pumps deliver alternately. Sometimes double-acting pumps are substituted, while very frequently there are two steam cylinders in the arrangement shown. The pump valve bores are formed in the supporting columns which act as air vessels."], "other": ["Inv. 1887-131"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["VERTICAL STEAM PUMP"], "makers": ["Alexander Wilson & Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1871"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a small direct-acting plunger pump, with a flywheel for controlling the motion and working the slide valve.", "The steam cylinder is above, and, on its cover, carries the bearings of the flywheel shaft.", "The piston rod forms the plunger and is consequently large\u2014thus reducing the speed when little steam taken on the up-stroke when but little work is being done.", "From the plunger projects a form of crosshead sliding on a vertical guide, and from the crosshead extends upward a connecting rod to a crankpin on the flywheel.", "At the other end of the flywheel shaft is a small overhanging crank, working a block capable of sliding in a slot formed in an extension of the slide valve rod. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["FEED PUMP (working)"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1907"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a direct-acting suction and force pump for boiler feeding, etc. The flywheel, controlling the slide valve of the steam cylinder through an eccentric, is driven without the intervention of a connecting rod by a block on the crankpin, sliding in a slot at right angles to its length in the common piston rod which thus has a simple harmonic motion. The suction and delivery valves are of the mushroom type. The steam cylinder is 2 in. diam. and the plunger 1\u00b72 in. diam. with a common stroke of 1\u00b79 in."], "other": ["Inv. 1907-45"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIRECT-ACTING STEAM PUMP (working)"], "makers": ["J. Stannah, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1891", "1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This machine, patented in 1876 by Mr. Stannah, has the steam cylinder above and a single-acting pump below, the large piston rod being carried down to form the pump plunger.", "The cylinder, framing, and pump are all in one casting.", "Projecting from the piston rod is a stud, on which is a flywheel free to revolve.", "At another point within the flywheel is attached the free end of a connecting rod, the other end of which is capable of swinging on a fixed centre on the cylinder front.", "As the flywheel is driven up and down the connecting rod compels it to rotate, and the momentum carries the engines over the dead centres.", "The motion of the connecting rod actuates a small cylindrical slide valve by which the distribution of steam to the cylinder is effected.", "By imagining the connecting rod to be fixed, and the rest of the engine to be free to swing, it will be seen that the arrangement is equivalent to an oscillating cylinder engine with the steam distribution by the motion of the trunnions.", "This example has a 1.75 in. cylinder, 0.875 in. plunger, and a stroke of 2.25 in., and is intended to make 110 revs. per min."], "other": ["Inv. 1892-125", "working"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Stannah's Patent pendulum steam pump, No.1", "Motive Power steam pump", "steam pump"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["pendulum"], "other": ["No.1"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIRECT-ACTING STEAM PUMP (working)"], "makers": ["J. Bernays, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1892", "1884"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["remarkable for the arrangement of crank and connecting rod by which the flywheel is connected with the reciprocating plunger, the result being that the stroke of the ram is twice the diameter of the crank path.", "arranged with the steam cylinder at one end, the large piston rod of which is carried through and forms the plunger of a single-acting pump at the opposite end of the machine.", "flywheel and shaft with an overhanging crank are placed midway, the crankpin being connected with a pin on the pump ram by a connecting rod whose effective length is equal to the radius of the crank path.", "connecting rod is produced backwards, and terminates in a circular end which engages alternately in two notches formed in a portion of the framing or the extremity of the short arm of the flywheel shaft.", "outer extremity of the short connecting rod is in this way controlled, and the kinematic chain closed during the time it would otherwise be incomplete.", "result is that the throw of the crank is increased by the length of the connecting rod at each end of the stroke.", "adjacent diagram shows the positions of crank and connecting rod at various portions of a revolution, the connecting rod being coloured blue, the ram red, and the stationary notches grey.", "admission of steam is controlled by an ordinary eccentric and slide valve, but when required to drive by hand, a handle is inserted in the fly-wheel.", "suction and delivery valves are contained in boxes with circular flanges, which can be bolted on to suit a horizontal or vertical arrangement of the pump."], "other": ["Inv. 1892-126"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Patented in 1884 by J. Bernays."], "other": ["SMG ID: 1939-486"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIRECT-ACTING STEAM PUMP"], "makers": ["Miller & Tupp"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1901", "1884"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["small boiler feed-pump", "constructed upon a system patented by Mr. J. J. Miller in 1884", "The steam cylinder and the pump are a single casting, and the piston rod forms the pump plunger; on one side of the cylinder is a chamber containing a crank-disc fixed to the shaft of an external flywheel, while an eccentric hole in this disc receives the spherical end of a pin projecting from the elongated piston of the steam cylinder. The piston as it reciprocates therefore turns the fly-wheel, and the engine itself undergoes continuous rotary motion. In the cylinder wall there are two steam ports, considerable to-and-fro movement between them, while the piston has two axial grooves and an exhaust port between their top and bottom faces respectively, the arrangement being such that the piston, by its rotating motion, acts as its own slide valve and gives a steam distribution similar to that obtained by the use of an eccentric without angular advance (see also No. 122).", "The cylinder is 1.1 in. diam. by 0.68 in. stroke and the plunger is 0.56 in. diam."], "other": ["Inv. 1901-40", "No. 122"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MULTIPLE DISC VALVE"], "makers": ["Metallic Valve Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1922", "1886"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This feed pump valve, patented by Mr. J. G. Kinghorn in 1886, is designed for high pressures.", "Shock is much reduced by the independent action of each disc and by the cushioning effect of the film of water formed between them.", "It is claimed to be lighter than other types of valves for the same service.", "The valve consists of three superimposed discs, of decreasing diameters, made of a tough rust-resisting metal, which are free to move independently on a fixed central stud, the lowest disc resting normally on the flat seating.", "The two lower discs are perforated in such a way that the openings can never overlap.", "A heavy guard is fitted to limit the valve opening, and this contains a helical spring, which tends to keep the valve shut.", "When water is forced through the valve the discs lift and some of the water flows through the perforations and between the discs, forming films which act as cushions when the valve strikes the guard. A similar action occurs on closing. In this way shock and wear are reduced, giving the valve a long life.", "When dealing with a large quantity of water it is better to use several small valves of this type rather than a single large one."], "other": ["Presented by", "Inv. 1922-615"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1864-65"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["independent adjustment, since if too much water be drawn in by the inductive action of the steam jet, the combined stream will not have sufficient velocity to force its way into the boiler.", "The action of the injector is more fully realised when it is remembered that the steam from a boiler issues into the atmosphere with a velocity that may be fifteen times as great as that of a water jet from the same boiler; this steam may, however, be condensed in five times its weight of water, so that after the distribution of the momentum of the steam jet into the mass of the combined jet a final velocity more than double that of a simple water jet from the boiler is obtained.", "This high velocity energy is converted into pressure energy more than sufficient to overcome the boiler pressure, by the slight divergence of the combining or delivery cone, which acts as a Bernoulli tube.", "independent adjustment", "inductive action of the steam jet", "combined stream will not have sufficient velocity to force its way into the boiler", "steam from a boiler issues into the atmosphere with a velocity that may be fifteen times as great as that of a water jet from the same boiler", "steam may, however, be condensed in five times its weight of water", "distribution of the momentum of the steam jet into the mass of the combined jet", "final velocity more than double that of a simple water jet from the boiler is obtained", "high velocity energy is converted into pressure energy more than sufficient to overcome the boiler pressure", "slight divergence of the combining or delivery cone, which acts as a Bernoulli tube"], "other": ["19,236"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["COMPOUND INJECTOR"], "makers": ["K\u00f6rting Bros."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1885"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This construction of double injector was patented by Mr. E. K\u00f6rting in 1873 and 1876. It consists of two slightly different Giffard injectors (see No. 452), arranged in series, so that the first, or lifter, feeds the other, or forcer, which delivers into the boiler. The delivery chambers of both lifter and forcer communicate with the overflow pipe by a three-way starting cock; the latter and the two conical steam valves are manipulated by a single hand-lever. When starting, the lever is moved through a part only of its travel, thus slightly opening the steam valves and at the same time opening both delivery chambers to overflow; the arrangement then readily lifts water by its steam exhauster action. The handle is then moved right over, so as to open fully both steam valves and close completely the overflow, after which the forcing injector feeds into the boiler."], "other": ["Inv. 1885-153"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["EXHAUST INJECTOR"], "makers": ["Hamer", "Davies"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1877\u201380"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["sectioned example of the injector patented by Messrs. Hamer, Metcalfe, and Davies, in 1877\u201380, in which, by an important modification in the usual construction, self-starting is secured and the apparatus is enabled to work with the exhaust steam from an engine, instead of requiring live steam from the boiler.", "The injector consists of a cast-iron casing containing the usual three nozzles, the steam nozzle, however, being exceptionally large on account of the large volume of steam to be passed, and having a conical spike in its centre to assist in concentrating the steam.", "The combining nozzle is the leading feature, however, as it is split or divided into two parts over a portion of its length by an axial plane, and one of these parts is hinged to the main portion at its upper end, so as to become a movable flap.", "The combining and delivery nozzles are connected together, and the water supply orifice beyond them is rendered adjustable by means of a nut at the delivery end.", "The overflow pipe has a chamber with a partition across it, which forms a water seal, and so prevents the entry of air into the combining cone.", "When starting, the steam and water escape freely into the overflow by the open flap, but when the combined jet acquires such a velocity as to be capable of feeding the boiler its exhaustive action becomes sufficient to close the flap, so that the water passes into the boiler through the delivery pipe.", "These injectors will, with exhaust steam, feed against a pressure of about 75 lb. per sq. in.; if required to supply a boiler at a higher pressure, an extra steam nozzle, supplied with boiler steam, is added to assist in the work; or else a supplementary injector supplied with boiler steam is used, which takes the water, already heated and raised to a considerable pressure by the exhaust injector, along into the boiler."], "other": ["Inv. 1902-140"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1888"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a sectioned example of an injector patented by Messrs. Holden and Brooke in 1884, and is specially constructed and proportioned for working with the exhaust steam from an engine, instead of requiring live steam from the boiler.", "The principle is the same as that of the ordinary Giffard's injector (see No. 452), but the details are modified to suit the lower pressure of steam employed; the apparatus is, however, even more remarkable than the original form, since by it the exhaust steam forces the feed into the boiler against the full steam pressure.", "A large annular conical nozzle is provided for the steam jet in consequence of the great volume of low-pressure steam.", "In starting, the steam and water escape freely by an opening in the combining tube and through a clack valve to the overflow; when this jet acquires the necessary velocity to enable it to overcome the pressure, the accompanying exhaustive action causes the overflow clack to close. The injector is self-starting, as the overflow automatically opens when feeding ceases."], "other": ["Lent by Messrs. Holden & Brooke", "No. 452", "Inv. 1888-284, 19,744"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ONE-MOVEMENT RE-STARTING INJECTOR", "original injector", "injector", "one handle injector"], "makers": ["Messrs. Holden & Brooke, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1921", "1890"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale full size", "only one handle was used for starting the injector and regulating the water and steam supply", "patented by Mr. R. G. Brooke", "embodies several improvements", "although not compound, can work with comparatively hot feed water", "The control handle is fixed to a spindle, which is free to revolve but is incapable of longitudinal motion within the body of the injector.", "Near the lower end of the spindle is a quick-threaded screw and at its extremity is a cone valve.", "The steam nozzle has a sleeve on its nut engaging with the thread on this spindle, and the nozzle and nut are free to slide longitudinally, but not revolve, within the injector casing, a gland being used to prevent steam leakage.", "The combining cone is fixed and divided near the centre of its length by the main overflow gap.", "The outlet from the overflow chamber is regulated by an automatic valve.", "There is also an overflow gap between the combining and delivery cones.", "The injector body is made in two parts and can easily be taken down, while provision is made for the lubrication of the chief working parts.", "When the starting handle is in the closed position the steam nozzle is screwed up to its highest point so that the cone valve on the spindle closes the entrance to the steam nozzle.", "As the handle is turned the steam nozzle is forced downwards away from the cone valve and nearer to the combining cone.", "The effect of this movement is at first gradually to open the steam inlet, while the water has practically free access to the combining cone, and later, while the steam passage remains fully open, the lower end of the steam nozzle approaches so close to the combining cone as to reduce the water inlet area, and thus the water supply can be reduced to about one-half of the full delivery.", "The injector is restarting and can be used for lifting.", "With no lift and steam at 160 lb. per sq. in. it can take feed-water at 115\u00b0 F. (46\u00b0 C.), or at 135\u00b0 F. (56\u00b0 C.) if the pressure is only 50 lb. per sq. in."], "other": ["DRAWING", "Inv. 1921-259"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["EXHAUST STEAM INJECTOR"], "makers": ["Messrs. Davies & Metcalfe, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1908"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a sectioned example of an injector patented in 1908 by Messrs. J. J. C. and R. D. Metcalfe.", "Owing to the use of two exhaust steam nozzles in series it can deliver against a pressure of 120 lb. per sq. in., instead of only about 75 lb. per sq. in. as in the single jet type (see 455).", "The exhaust steam from the engine passes into the ejector through a hand-controlled wing valve, after which part of it passes through the central exhaust steam nozzle and part through the annular nozzle surrounding the draft tube.", "The combining nozzle is of the flap type, arranged to give a very free outlet, and an automatic hinged valve is fitted to the overflow chamber.", "When the wing valve is opened steam passes into the injector. When the water, which must be under a slight head, is turned on it passes through the injector to the overflow mixing with the exhaust steam and condensing it, thus causing a partial vacuum which draws in more steam.", "In this way in a short time the velocity of the steam through the two nozzles is sufficient to give the necessary momentum to the water.", "The condensation of steam and the giving up of its momentum takes place in two stages, thus increasing efficiency and enabling the delivery pressure to reach as high a value as 120 lb. per sq. in.", "In other respects the injector works like the usual automatic live steam injector.", "The water supply is regulated by moving the central exhaust nozzle, which can slide longitudinally within the injector body towards the draft tube, thus reducing the annular area through which the water has to pass.", "This movement is performed by means of an eccentric pin fitting in a slot on the outside of the nozzle and worked by the external water regulator handle.", "For working the injector when the engine is not running a live steam connection is provided.", "The main body of the injector is of cast iron, but all nozzles are of gunmetal and can be easily removed."], "other": ["N/A", "Inv. 1921-431."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Vaughan"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1886", "1895-57"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["sectioned example", "steam trap for a 3 in. pipe", "consists of a cast-iron vessel fitted with two deflectors by which the steam and its contained water are thrown into the lower portion of the vessel where the water settles by gravity.", "From the chamber the water escapes by a pipe, communicating with an automatic valve so constructed that it will allow the water to pass but not the steam. This is accomplished by using a horizontal iron pipe carrying at its end a hand-wheel and a stop valve, and having within it a copper pipe which carries the seat of the valve at one end but is rigidly fixed only at the opposite extremity. The valve is slightly withdrawn from its seat so as to let the water escape, but when all the water is exhausted and steam enters the copper pipe the greater expansion of copper (about 50 per cent. more than iron) elongates the internal tube sufficiently to close the valve. After a while the further accumulation of water in the collecting chamber cools the copper tube sufficiently to open the valve again. By opening the valve wide, a complete blow through for scouring purposes can be effected."], "other": ["Inv."]}

Ogden"], "organisations/institutions": ["United Asbestos Co., Ltd."], "dates": ["1904-5", "1898"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["action depends on the expansion and contraction of a tube operating the valve through which the condensed water is discharged", "consists of a tube of brass, or other metal with a high coefficient of expansion, connected at one end with a valve casing, the other end being secured to a flange attached to the steam piping which it is required to drain", "Two iron rods are mounted with their inner ends carried in a collar pivoted on the end flange, and with their outer ends carried, one against the valve casing and the other against the shorter arm of a spring-loaded lever", "lever operating against the steam pressure bears against the discharge valve spindle and keeps the valve closed", "When the trap is cold, it is arranged that the valve is open owing to the pressure of the upper iron rod on the shorter arm of the bellcrank lever. Condensed water then collects in the brass tube, and, as its temperature falls, the tube contracts, thus opening the valve, when the same series of operations recurs.", "effect of the expansion of the brass tube is magnified, first by the bellcrank lever having unequal arms, and then it is doubled by having a pair of iron rods and making the collar against which they bear pivot about the end flange on knife edges"], "other": ["lent by"]}

Geipel", "particular attention has been directed to preventing the loss of steam commonly met with at the valve and that occasioned by excessive radiating surface", "eliminating levers and pivots and to rendering the valve readily accessible", "The float or bucket and the chamber are cylindrical as this gives small area for a given floatation power", "The bucket has a central stem, which is guided by wings in a tube, and has at its upper end a pilot valve closing, when the bucket is empty, on a seating free to move on the stem itself; this seating in turn acts as the valve of a larger seating open to the discharge", "Thus a large opening is provided when the steam pressure is low, i.e., when steam is first turned on and the condensation is great, or a small opening when the pressure is high", "These valves and valve seats are made of nickel and are renewable", "To examine the valve, the upper part carrying with it the main valve seating can be unscrewed and in doing so this does not involve breaking a steam joint", "To blow through it is only necessary to depress the knob on the top; this pushes the main valve off its seat", "The trap shown is stated to be suitable for a discharge of 100 gall. per hour, equivalent to a pipe surface of 500 sq. ft., at a pressure from 10 to 200 lb.", "The trap is screwed for a 0.75 in. pipe."], "other": ["Inv. 1920-11", "S.M. 1230", "Presented by", "sectioned example"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF STIRLING'S HOT-AIR ENGINE"], "makers": ["Dr. Robert Stirling"], "organisations/institutions": ["University of Edinburgh"], "dates": ["1816"], "places": ["United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["This is a replica in section of the model preserved in the University of Edinburgh, of the hot air engine designed and constructed by Dr. Robert Stirling, in 1816.", "His design is of interest in that it was an attempt to construct an engine working similarly to the theoretically perfect heat engine in which the cycle of operations is closed, the same mass of air being used throughout.", "The heat was distributed by means of a \u201cdisplacer\u201d which moved the mass of air to and fro between the hot and cold portions of the apparatus;", "Stirling also compressed the air before heating it.", "He was the first to apply a \u201cregenerator\u201d to absorb and restore alternately some of the heat of the mass of working fluid.", "In these ways he greatly improved the practical efficiency of this class of motor.", "In the model the furnace portion, probably coke-heated, is missing as in the original."], "other": ["Inv. 1923-419"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF HOT-AIR ENGINE"], "makers": ["P. R. Hodge, Esq.", "Mr. H. Messer"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1807", "1863-4", "1867-42"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This engine is of the original type designed by Sir G. Cayley in 1807, in which is employed a closed furnace and two cylinders: a small or cold cylinder, forcing air into and around the furnace, and a larger one into which this heated air is admitted to perform the working strokes, afterwards being discharged into the atmosphere. The model embodies improvements patented by Mr. H. Messer in 1863-4, and has the hot cylinder and the furnace arranged in a rectangular base with the space between them filled with non-conducting material. The furnace itself is a firebrick chamber with a perforated bottom, closed above by a removable charging door. Air from the atmosphere is, by the cold cylinder, pumped into the casing of the furnace, where it is heated, while some of it maintains the combustion of the fuel. The heated air and gases then pass to the hot cylinder, where, on account of their greater volume, they perform much more work than was absorbed in working the air pump, the difference being the available power for overcoming the friction of the engine and doing external work. The cylinders are both single-acting, and are connected with opposite cranks on a shaft above. The admission and exhaust valves of the hot cylinder are of the drop type, and are controlled by cams operated by an eccentric on the crankshaft."], "other": ["(Scale 1: 8.)", "(Engine designed by Sir G. Cayley; improvements by Mr. H. Messer.)", "Inv."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["hot air engine of the Cayley type"], "makers": ["Messer"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1807", "1863-4"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Heat Engines (non steam) model"], "other": ["(scale 1:8)"]}

Bailey & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1894", "1845"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["constructed on Stirling\u2019s principle", "after Laubereau\u2019s which this end is kept cool.", "The cold end is fitted with an air-tight piston, which, through two connecting-rods and a weigh-shaft, is coupled to a crank on the fly-wheel shaft.", "To another crankpin on the second weigh-shaft is coupled, and this is connected with a rod passing through a gland in the piston, and attached to the \u201cdisplacer.\u201d", "This displacer is a loosely fitting plunger, which is supported by a roller in the cylinder, and its office is to push the air from the hot end of the cylinder to the cold end and back again, as required.", "The only valve is a small one, fixed to the cylinder and opening inward, so that any air lost by leakage is replaced whenever the internal pressure falls below that of the atmosphere.", "The same air is worked continuously, being alternately heated and cooled during each revolution of the crankshaft.", "At the commencement of the outward stroke of the piston the displacer is at the cool end of the cylinder, and the bulk of the air, which is accordingly at the hot end, is being heated, so increasing in pressure and driving the piston outward.", "This movement rotates the crankshaft, and so moves the displacer towards the hot end, thus causing the hot air to pass to the cool end of the cylinder, where the pressure falls through the reduction of temperature due to the cold water-jacket, and the return stroke of the piston then takes place, under the action of the fly-wheel.", "The work given off is the difference between that done by the air during the outward stroke of the piston and that done upon it during
